titleStmt.title: A king, and no king. Beaumont, Francis, 1584-1616 / Fletcher, John, 1579-1625 : : A king, and no king (1679)

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by J. Macock, for John Martyn, Henry Herringman, Richard Marriot

sourceDesc.p: From the 1679 Beaumont and Fletcher Folio, Wing B1582

Play details
A king, and no king. Genre: Tragi-comedy. Date first published: 1619. Date first performed: 1611.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Mardonius Bessus Spaconia King Arbaces Tigranus 1 Gent. 2 Gent. Messenger Lygonas Gobrias Bacurius Arane Panthe 1 man/sword 2man/sword 3man Woman 1 Citizen 2 Citizen Philip 3 Wom. 4 3 Gent. Omnes Servant
UNK

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div2.stage: Enter Mardonius and Bessus, two Captains.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Bessus, the King has made a fair hand of it, he
has ended the Wars at a blow, would my
sword had a close basket hilt to hold Wine,
and the blade would make knives, for we
shall have nothing but eating and drinking.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: We that are Commanders shall do well enough.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Faith Bessus, such Commanders as thou may; I had
as lieve set thee Perdue for a pudding in the dark, as Alexander the Great.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I love these jests exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I think thou lovest them better than quarrelling Bessus,
I will say so much in thy behalf, and yet thou art valiant enough upon a retreat, I think thou wouldst kill any man that stopped thee if thou couldst.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: But was not this a brave Combat Mardonius?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, didst thou see it?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: You stood with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I did so, but methought thou winkedst every blow
they struck.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Well, I believe there are better soldiers than I,
that never saw two Princes fight in lists.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
By my troth I think so too Bessus, many a thousand,
but certainly all that are worse than thou have seen as much.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: It was bravely done of our King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Yes, if he had not ended the wars: I am glad
thou darest talk of such dangerous businesses.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: To take a Prince prisoner in the heart of his own Country in single combat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
See how thy blood curdles at this, I think thou
couldst be contented to be beaten in this passion.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Shall I tell you truly?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I could willingly venture for it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Um, no venture neither Bessus.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Let me not live, if I do not think it is a braver piece
of service than that I am so famed for.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, art thou famed for any valour?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Famed! I, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
I am even heartily glad of it, I have been with thee
ever since thou camest to the wars, and this is the first word
that ever I heard of it, prithee who fames thee.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: The Christian world.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
It is heathenishly done of them in my conscience, thou
deserve it not.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Yes, I have done good service.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I do not know how thou mayst wait of a man in his
Chamber, or thy agility of shifting of a Trencher, but otherwise
no service good Bessus.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: You saw me do the service yourself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Not so hasty sweet Bessus, where was it, is the
place vanished?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: At Bessus desperate redemption.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: At Bessus desperate redemption, where is that?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
There where I redeemed the day, the place bears my
name.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray thee, who Christened it?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: The Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
If I were not a very merrily disposed man, what would
become of thee? one that had but a grain of choler in the
whole composition of his body, would send thee of an errand
to the worms for putting thy name upon that field: did not
I beat thee there in the head of the Troops with a Truncheon,
because thou wouldst needs run away with thy company,
when we should charge the enemy?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: True, but I did not run.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Right Bessus, I beat thee out of it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
But came I not up when the day was gone, and redeemed
all?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Thou knowest, and so do I, thou meanedest to fly,
and thy fear making thee mistake, thou ranst upon the enemy,
and a hot charge thou gavest, as I will to thee right, thou art
furious in running away, and I think, we owe thy fear for
our victory; If I were the King, and were sure thou wouldst
mistake always and run away upon the enemy, thou shouldest
be General by this light.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: You will never leave this till I fall foul.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
No more such words dear Bessus, for though I have
ever known thee a coward, and therefore durst never strike
thee, yet if thou proceedest, I will allow thee valiant, and
beat thee.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Come, our King is a brave fellow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
He is so Bessus, I wonder how thou camest to know
it. But if thou wert a man of understanding, I would tell
thee, he is vain-glorious, and humble, and angry, and
patient, and merry and dull, and joyful and sorrowful in
extremity in an hour: Do not think me thy friend for this,
for if I cared who knew it, thou shouldest not hear it Bessus.
Here he is with his prey in his foot.

div2.stage: Enter Arbaces and Tigranes, two Kings and two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Thy sadness brave Tigranes takes away
From my full victory, am I become
Of so small fame, that any man should grieve
When I overcome him? They that placed me here,
Intended it an honour large enough,
For the most valiant living, but to dare oppose me single, though he
Lost the day. What should afflict you, you are as free as I,
To be my prisoner, is to be more free
Than you were formerly, and never think
The man I held worthy to combat me
Shall be used servilely: Thy ransom is
To take my only Sister to thy Wife.
A heavy one Tigranes, for she is
A Lady, that the neighbour Princes send
Blanks to fetch home. I have been too unkind
To her Tigranes, she but nine years old
I left her and never saw her since, your wars
Have held me long and taught me though a youth,
The way to victory, she was a pretty child,
Then I was little better, but now fame
Cries loudly on her, and my messengers
Make me believe she is a miracle;
She will make you shrink, as I did, with a stroke
But of her eye Tigranes.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Is it the course of Iberia to use their prisoners thus?
Had fortune thrown my name above Arbace,
I should not thus have talked Sir, in Armenia,
We hold it base, you should have kept your temper
Till you saw home again, where it is the fashion
Perhaps to brag.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Be you my witness earth, need I to brag,
Doth not this captive Prince speak
Me sufficiently, and all the acts
That I have wrought upon his suffering Land;
Should I then boast! where lies that foot of ground
Within his whole Realm, that I have not past,
Fighting and conquering; Far then from me
Be ostentation. I could tell the world
How I have laid his Kingdom desolate
By this sole Arm propped by divinity,
Stripped him out of his glories, and have sent
The pride of all his youth to people graves,
And made his Virgins languish for their Loves,
If I would brag, should I that have the power
To teach the Neighbour world humility,
Mix with vain-glory?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed this is none.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Tigranes, Nay did I but take delight
To stretch my deeds as others do, on words,
I could amaze my hearers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So you do.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
But he shall wrong his and my modesty,
That thinks me apt to boast after any act
Fit for a good man to do upon his foe.
A little glory in a soldier's mouth
Is well-becoming, be it far from vain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It is pity that valour should be thus drunk.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I offer you my Sister, and you answer
I do insult, a Lady that no suite
Nor treasure; nor thy Crown could purchase thee,
But that thou foughtest with me.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Though this be worse
Than that you spake before, it strikes me not;
But that you think to overgrace me with
The marriage of your Sister, troubles me.
I would give worlds for ransoms were they mine,
Rather than have her.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
See if I insult
That am the Conqueror, and for a ransom
Offer rich treasure to the Conquered,
Which he refuses, and I bear his scorn:
It cannot be self-flattery to say,
The Daughters of your Country set by her,
Would see their shame, run home and blush to death,
At their own foulness; yet she is not fair,
Nor beautiful, those words express her not,
They say her looks have something excellent,
That wants a name: yet were she odious,
Her birth deserves the Empire of the world,
Sister to such a brother, that hath taken
Victory prisoner, and throughout the earth,
Carries her bound, and should he let her loose,
She durst not leave him; Nature did her wrong,
To Print continual conquest on her cheeks,
And make no man worthy for her to taste
But me that am too near her, and as strangely
She did for me, but you will think I brag.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I do I will be sworn. Thy valour and thy passions severed,
would have made two excellent fellows in their kinds:
I know not whether I should be sorry thou art so valiant, or
so passionate, would one of them were away.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Do I refuse her that I doubt her worth?
Were she as virtuous as she would be thought,
So perfect that no one of her own sex
Could find a want, had she so tempting fair,
That she could wish it off for damning souls,
I would pay any ransom, twenty lives
Rather than meet her married in my bed.
Perhaps I have a love, where I have fixed
Mine eyes not to be moved, and she on me,
I am not fickle.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Is that all the cause?
Think you, you can so knit yourselfin love
To any other, that her searching sight
Cannot dissolve it? So before you tried,
You thought yourselfa match for me in sight,
Trust me Tigranes, she can do as much
in peace, as I in war, she will conquer too,
You shall see if you have the power to stand
The force of her swift looks, if you dislike,
I will send you home with love, and name your ransom
Some other way, but if she be your choice,
She frees you: To Iberia you must.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Sir, I have learned a prisoners sufferance,
And will obey, but give me leave to talk
In private with some friends before I go.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Some to await him forth, and see him safe,
But let him freely send for whom he please,
And none dare to disturb his conference,
I will not have him know what bondage is,
Till he be free from me. This Prince, Mardonius,
Is full of wisdom, valour, all the graces
Man can receive.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And yet you conquered him.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
And yet I conquered him, and could have done it
Hadst thou joined with him, though thy name in Arms
Be great; must all men that are virtuous
Think suddenly to match themselves with me?
I conquered him and bravely, did I not?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: And please your Majesty, I was afraid at first.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: When wert thou other?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Bes.
Mar.
sp.p: Like a Taylor at a wake.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
And then, if please your Majesty to remember, at
one time, by my troth I wished myself with you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By my troth thou wouldst have stunk them both out of the Lists.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
To put your Majesty in mind of an occasion; you
lay thus, and Tigranes falsified a blow at your Leg, which
you by doing thus avoided; but if you had whipped up your
Leg thus, and reached him on the ear, you had made the
Blood-Royal run down his head.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What Country Fence-school learnest thou at?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Pish, did not I take him nobly?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why you did, and you have talked enough of it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Talked enough?
Will you confine my word? by heaven and earth,
I were much better be a King of beasts
Than such a people: if I had not patience
Above a God, I should be called a Tyrant
Throughout the world. They will offend to death
Each minute: Let me hear thee speak again,
And thou art earth again: why this is like
Tigranes speech that needs would say I bragged.
Bessus, he said I bragged.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why dost thou laugh?
By all the world, I am grown ridiculous
To my own Subjects: Tie me in a Chair
And jest at me, but I shall make a start,
And punish some that others may take heed
How they are haughty; who will answer me?
He said I boasted, speak Mardonius,
Did I? He will not answer, O my temper!
I give you thanks above, that taught my heart
Patience, I can endure his silence; what will none
Vouchsafe to give me answer? am I grown
To such a poor respect, or do you mean
To break my wind? Speak, speak, some one of you,
Or else by heaven.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: So please your.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Monstrous,
I cannot be heard out, they cut me off,
As if I were too saucy, I will live
In woods, and talk to trees, they will allow me
To end what I begin. The meanest Subject
Can find a freedom to discharge his soul
And not I, now it is a time to speak,
I hearken.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: May it please.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I mean not you,
Did not I stop you once? but I am grown
To balk, but I defy, let another speak,

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I hope your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Thou drawest thy words,
That I must wait an hour, where other men
Can hear in instants; throw your words away,
Quick, and to purpose, I have told you this.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: And please your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Wilt thou devour me? this is such a rudeness
As you never showed me, and I want
Power to command too, else Mardonius
Would speak at my request; were you my King,
I would have answered at your word Mardonius,
I pray you speak, and truly, did I boast?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Truth will offend you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
You take all great care what will offend me,
When you dare to utter such things as these.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
You told Tigranes, you had won his Land,
With that sole arm propped by Divinity:
Was not that bragging, and a wrong to us,
That daily ventured lives?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
O that thy name
Were as great, as mine, would I had paid my wealth,
It were as great, as I might combat thee,
I would through all the Regions habitable
Search thee, and having found thee, with my Sword
Drive thee about the world, till I had met
Some place that yet man's curiosity
Hath missed of; there, there would I strike thee dead:
Forgotten of mankind, such Funeral rites
As beasts would give thee, thou shouldest have.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
The King rages extremely, shall we slink away?
He will strike us.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
There I would make you know it was this sole arm
I grant you were my instruments, and did
As I commanded you, but it was this arm
Moved you like wheels, it moved you as it pleased.
Whither slip you now? what are you too good
To wait on me (puff,) I had need have temper
That rule such people; I have nothing left
At my own choice, I would I might be private:
Mean men enjoy themselves, but it is our curse,
To have a tumult that out of their loves
Will wait on us, whether we will or no;
Go get you gone: Why here they stand like death,
My words move nothing.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Must we go?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I pray you leave me Sirs, I am proud of this,
That you will be entreated from my sight:
Why now the leave me all: Mardonius.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Will you leave me quite alone? methinks
Civility should teach you more than this,
If I were but your friend: Stay here and wait.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir shall I speak?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why, you would now think much
To be denied, but I can scare entreat
What I would have: do, speak.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But will you hear me out?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
With me you Article to talk thus: well,
I will hear you out.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sir, that I have ever loved you, my sword hath
spoken for me; that I do, if it be doubted, I dare call an
oath, a great one to my witness; and were you not my King,
from amongst men, I should have chose you out to love above
the rest: nor can this challenge thanks, for my own
sake I should have done it, because I would have loved the
most deserving man, for so you are.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Alas Mardonius, rise you shall not kneel,
We all are soldiers, and all venture lives:
And where there is no difference in men's worths,
Titles are jests, who can outvalue thee?
Mardonius thou hast loved me, and hast wrong,
Thy love is not rewarded, but believe
It shall be better, more than friend in arms,
My Father, and my Tutor, good Mardonius.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, you did promise you would hear me out.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
And so I will; speak freely, for from thee
Nothing can come but worthy things and true.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Though you have all this worth, you hold some
qualities that do Eclipse your virtues.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Eclipse my virtues?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Yes, your passions, which are so manifold, that
they appear even in this: when I commend you, you hug
me for that truth: but when I speak your faults, you make
a start, and fly the hearing but.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
When you commend me? O that I should live
To need such commendations: If my deeds
Blew not my praise themselves about the earth,
I were most wretched: spare your idle praise:
If thou didst mean to flatter, and shouldest utter
Words in my praise, that thou thoughtest impudence,
My deeds should make them modest: when you praise I hug
you? it is so safe, that wert thou worthy thou shouldest receive
a death, a glorious death from me: but thou shalt understand
thy lies, for shouldest thou praise me into Heaven,
and there leave me enthroned, I would despise thee though as
much as now, which is as much as dust because I see thy envy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
However you will use me after, yet for your own
promise sake, hear me the rest.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I will, and after call unto the winds, for they shall
lend as large an ear as I to what you utter: speak.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Would you but leave these hasty tempers, which
I do not say take from you all your worth, but darken them,
then you will shine indeed.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Yet I would have you keep some passions, lest men
should take you for a God, your virtues are such.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why now you flatter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I never understood the word, were you no King,
and free from these moods, should I choose a companion
for wit and pleasure, it should be you; or for honesty to
interchange my bosom with, it should be you; or wisdom
to give me counsel, I would pick out you; or valour to
defend my reputation, still I should find you out; for you
are fit to fight for all the world, if it could come in question:
Now I have spoke, consider to yourself, find out a use;
if so, then what shall fall to me is not material.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Is not material? more than ten such lives, as mine,
Mardonius: it was nobly said, thou hast spoke truth, and
boldly such a truth as might offend another. I have been too
passionate and idle, thou shalt see a swift amendment, but
I want those parts you praise me for: I fight for all the
world? Give me a sword, and thou wilt go as far beyond
me, as thou art beyond in years, I know thou darest and
wilt; it troubles me that I should use so rough a phrase to
thee, impute it to my folly, what thou wilt, so thou wilt
pardon me: that thou and I should differ thus!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why it is no matter Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Faith but it is, but thou dost ever take all things I
do, thus patiently, for which I never can requite thee, but
with love, and that thou shalt be sure of. Thou and I have
not been merry lately: pray thee tell me where hadst thou
that same jewel in thine ear?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why at the taking of a Town.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
A wench upon my life, a wench Mardonius gave
thee that jewel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Wench! they respect not me, I am old and rough,
and every limb about me, but that which should, grows
stiffer, In those businesses I may swear I am truly honest: for
I pay justly for what I take, and would be glad to be at
a certainty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why, do the wenches encroach upon thee?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Aye by this light do they.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Didst thou sit at an old rent with them?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes faith.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And do they improve themselves?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Aye ten shillings to me, every new young fellow they
come acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How canst live on it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why I think I must petition to you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Thou shalt take them up at my price.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your price?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Aye at the Kings price.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That may be more than I am worth.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Is he not merry now?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I think not.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: He is, he is: we will show ourselves.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Bessus, I thought you had been in Iberia by this, I
bad you haste; Gobrias will want entertainment for me.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: If it please your Majesty I have a suit.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Is it not lousy Bessus, what is it?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I am to carry a Lady with me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Then thou hast two suits.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
And if I can prefer her to the Lady Pentha your Majesties
Sister, to learn fashions, as her friends term it, it
will be worth something to me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: So many nights lodgings as it is thither, wilt not?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I know not that Sir, but gold I shall be sure of.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why thou shalt bid her entertain her from me, so
thou wilt resolve me one thing.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: If I can.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Faith it is a very disputable question, and yet I
think thou canst decide it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Your Majesty has a good opinion of my understanding.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I have so good an opinion of it: it is whether thou
be valiant.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Somebody has traduced me to you: do you see
this sword Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
If I do not make my backbiters eat it to a knife
within this week, say I am not valiant.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Health to your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: From Gobrias?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How does he, is he well?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: In perfect health.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Take that for thy good news. A trustier servant
to his Prince there lives not, than is good Gobrias.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: The Kings starts back.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: His blood goes back as fast.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: And now it comes again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He alters strangely.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
The hand of Heaven is on me, be it far from me to
struggle, if my secret sins have pulled this curse upon me,
lend me tears now to wash me white, that I may feel a
child-like innocence within my breast; which once performed,
O give me leave to stand as fixed as constancy herself,
my eyes set here unmoved, regardless of the world
though thousand miseries encompass me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is strange, Sir, how do you?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Mardonius, my mother.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is she dead?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Alas she is not so happy, thou dost know how she
hath laboured since my Father died to take by treason hence
this loathed life, that would but be to serve her, I have
pardoned, and pardoned, and by that have made her sit to
practise new sins, not repent the old: she now had stirred a
slave to come from thence, and strike me here, whom Gobrias
sifting out, took and condemned and executed there,
the carefullest servant: Heaven let me but live to pay that
man; Nature is poor to me, that will not let me have as
many deaths as are the times that he hath saved my life, that
I might dye them over all for him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sir let her bear her sins on her own head,
Vex not yourself.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
What will the world
Conceive of me? with what unnatural sins
Will they suppose me laden, when my life
Is sought by her that gave it to the world?
But yet he writes me comfort here, my Sister,
He says, is grown in beauty and in grace.
In all the innocent virtues that become
A tender spotless maid: she stains her cheeks
With morning tears to purge her mothers ill,
And amongst that sacred dew she mingles Prayers
Her pure Oblations for my safe return:
If I have lost the duty of a Son,
If any pomp or vanity of state
Made me forget my natural offices,
Nay farther, if I have not every night
Expostulated with my wandering thoughts,
If ought unto my parent they have erred,
And called them back: do you direct her arm
Unto this foul dissembling heart of mine:
But if I have been just to her, send out
Your power to compass me, and hold me safe
From searching treason; I will use no means
But prayer: for rather suffer me to see
From mine own veins issue a deadly flood,
Than wash my danger off with mothers blood.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I never saw such sudden extremities.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Why? wilt thou have me die Spaconia,
What should I do?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Nay let me stay alone,
And when you see Armenia again,
You shall behold a Tomb more worth than I;
Some friend that ever loved me or my cause,
Will build me something to distinguish me
From other women, many a weeping verse
He will lay on, and much lament those maids,
That placed their loves unfortunately high,
As I have done, where they can never reach;
But why should you go to Iberia?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Alas, that thou wilt ask me, ask the man
That rages in a Fever why he lies
Distempered there, when all the other youths
Are coursing over the Meadows with their Loves?
Can I resist it? am I not a slave
To him that conquered me?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
That conquered thee Tigranes! he has won
But half of thee, thy body, but thy mind
May be as free as his, his will did never
Combat thine, and take it prisoner.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
But if he by force convey my body hence,
What helps it me or thee to be unwilling?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
O Tigranes, I know you are to see a Lady there,
To see, and like I fear: perhaps the hope
Of her make you forget me, ere we part,
Be happier than you know to wish; farewell.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Spaconia, stay and hear me what I say:
In short, destruction meet me that I may
See it, and not avoid it, when I leave
To be thy faithful lover: part with me
Thou shalt not, there are none that know our love,
And I have given gold unto a Captain
That goes unto Iberia from the King,
That he will place a Lady of our Land
With the Kings Sister that is offered me;
Thither shall you, and being once got in
Persuade her by what subtle means you can
To be as backward in her love as I.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Can you imagine that a longing maid
When she beholds you, can be pulled away
With words from loving you?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Dispraise my health, my honesty, and tell her
I am jealous.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Why, I had rather lose you: can my heart
Consent to let my tongue throw out such words,
And I that ever yet spoke what I thought,
Shall find it such a thing at first to lie?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Yet do thy best.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: What, is your Majesty ready?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: There is the Lady, Captain.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Sweet Lady, by your leave, I could wish myself
more full of Courtship for your fair sake.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Sir I shall feel no want of that.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Lady, you must haste, I have received new letters
from the King that require more haste than I expected,
he will follow me suddenly himself, and begins to call for
your Majesty already.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: He shall not do so long.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, shall I call you my Charge hereafter?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
I will not take upon me to govern your tongue Sir,
you shall call me what you please.

div2.stage: Enter Gobrias, Bacurius, Arane, Panthe, and Mandane, Waiting-women with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
My Lord Bacurius, you must have regard unto the
Queen, she is your prisoner, it is at your peril if
she make escape.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
My Lord, I know it, she is my prisoner from you
committed; yet she is a woman, and so I keep her safe,
you will not urge me to keep her close, I shall not shame to
say I sorrow for her.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
So do I my Lord; I sorrow for her, that so little
grace doth govern her: that she should stretch her arm against
her King, so little womanhood and natural goodness,
as to think the death of her own Son.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p:
Thou knowest the reason why, dissembling as thou
art, and wilt not speak.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
There is a Lady takes not after you,
Her Father is within her, that good man
Whose tears weighed down his sins, mark how she weeps;
How well it does become her, and if you
Can find no disposition in yourself
To sorrow, yet by gracefulness in her
Find out the way, and by your reason weep:
All this she does for you, and more she needs
When for yourselfyou will not lose a tear,
Think how this want of grief discredits you,
And you will weep, because you cannot weep.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p:
You talk to me as having got a time fit for your
purpose; but you know I know you speak not what you
think.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I would my heart were Stone, before my softness should be urged
Against my mother, a more troubled thought
No Virgin bears about; should I excuse
My Mothers fault, I should set light a life
In losing which, a brother and a King
Were taken from me, if I seek to save
That life so loved, I lose another life
That gave me being, I shall lose a Mother,
A word of such a sound in a child's ears
That it strikes reverence through it; may the will
Of heaven be done, and if one needs must fall,
Take a poor Virgins life to answer all.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p:
But Gobrias let us talk, you know this fault
Is not in me as in another Mother.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: I know it is not.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Yet you make it so.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Why, is not all that is past beyond your help?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I know it is.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Nay should you publish it before the world,
Think you it would be believed?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I know it would not.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Nay should I join with you, should we not both be
torn and yet both die uncredited?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I think we should.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Why then take you such violent courses? As for
me I do but right in saving of the King from all your plots

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: The King?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
I bad you rest with patience, and a time
Would come for me to reconcile all to
Your own content, but by this way you take
Away my power, and what was done unknown,
Was not by me but you: your urging being done
I must preserve my own, but time may bring
All this to light, and happily for all.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p:
Accursed be this over curious brain
That gave that plot a birth, accursed this womb
That after did conceive to my disgrace.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
My Lord Protector, they say there are divers Letters
come from Armenia, that Bessus has done good service, and
brought again a day, by his particular valour, received you
any to that effect?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Yes, it is most certain.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
I amsorry for it, not that the day was won,
But that it was won by him: we held him here
A Coward, he did me wrong once, at which I laughed,
And so did all the world, for nor I,
Nor any other held him worth my sword.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Health to my Protector; from the King
These Letters; and to your grace Madam, these.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: How does his Majesty?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
As well as conquest by his own means and his valiant
Commanders can make him; your letters will tell you all.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I will not open mine till I do know
My Brothers health: good Captain is he well?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: As the rest of us that fought are.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: But how is that? is he hurt?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: He is a strange soldier that gets not a knock.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I do not ask how strange that soldier is
That gets no hurt, but whether he have one.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: He had divers.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And is he well again?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Well again, it it please your Grace: why I was run
twice through the body, and shot in the head with a cross-arrow,
and yet am well again.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do not care how thou dost, is he well?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Not care how I do? Let a man out of the mightiness
of his spirit, fructify Foreign Countries with his blood for
the good of his own, and thus he shall be answered: Why
I may live to relieve with spear and shield, such a Lady
as you distressed.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Why, I will care, I am glad that thou art well,
I prithee is he so?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: The King is well and will be here tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: My prayer is heard, now will I open mine.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Bacurius, I must ease you of your charge:
Madam, the wonted mercy of the King,
That overtakes your faults, has met with this,
And struck it out, he has forgiven you freely,
Your own will is your law, be where you please.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I thank him.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You will be ready to wait upon his Majesty tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Madam be wise hereafter; I am glad I have lost
this Office.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Good Captain Bessus, tell us the discourse betwixt
Tigranes and our King, and how we got the victory.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I prithee do, and if my Brother were
In any danger, let not thy tale make
Him abide there long before thou bring him off,
For all that while my heart will beat.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Madam let what will beat, I must tell the truth,
and thus it was; they fought single in lists, but one to one;
as for my own part, I was dangerously hurt but three days
before, else, perhaps, we had been two to two, I cannot
tell, some thought we had, and the occasion of my hurt
was this, the enemy had made Trenches.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Captain, without the manner of your hurt be much
material to this business, we will hear it some other time.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I prithee leave it, and go on with my Brother.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
I will, but it would be worth your hearing: To the
Lists they came, and single-sword and gantlet was their fight.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Without the Lists there stood some dozen Captains
of either side mingled, all which were sworn, and one of
those was I: and it was my chance to stand next a Captain
of the enemies side, called Tiribasus; Valiant they said he
was; whilst these two Kings were stretching themselves,
this Tiribasus cast something a scornful look on me, and asked
me who I thought would overcome: I smiled and told him
if he would fight with me, he should perceive by the event
of that whose King would win: something he answered,
and a scuffle was like to grow, when one Zipetus offered
to help him, I -

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
All this is of thyself, I pray thee Bessus tell something
of my Brother, did he nothing?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Why yes, I will tell your Grace, they were not to
fight till the word given, which for my own part, by my
troth I confess I was not to give.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: See for his own part.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I fear yet this fellow is abused with a good report.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: But I -

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Still of himself.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Cried give the word, when as some of them say, Tigranes
was stooping, but the word was not given then, yet
one Cosroes of the enemies part, held up his finger to me,
which is as much with us Martialists, as I will sight with
you: I said not a word, nor made sign during the combat,
but that once done.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: He slips over all the fight.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I called him to me, Cosroes said I.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I will hear no more.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: No, no, I lie.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I dare be sworn thou dost.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Captain said I, so it was.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I tell thee, I will hear no further.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: No? Your Grace will wish you had.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I will not wish it, what is this the Lady
My brother writes to me to take?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
If it please your Grace this is she: Charge, will you
come near the Princess?

sp.speaker: Pan.
Pan.
sp.p:
You are very welcome, you have got a letter to put
you to me, that has power enough to place mine enemy
here; then much more you that are so far from being so to
me that you never saw me.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Madam, I dare pass my word for her truth.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: My truth?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Why Captain, do you think I am afraid she will steal?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
I cannot tell, servants are slippery, but I dare give
my word for her, and for honesty, she came along with me,
and many favours she did me by the way, but by this light
none but what she might do with modesty, to a man of my
rank.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Why Captain, here is nobody thinks otherwise.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Nay, if you should, your Grace may think your pleasure;
but I am sure I brought her from Armenia, and in all
that way, if ever I touched any bare of her above her knee, I
pray God I may sink where I stand.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Above my knee?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
No, you know I did not, and if any man will say, I did,
this sword shall answer; Nay, I will defend the reputation of
my charge whilst I live, your Grace shall understand I am
secret in these businesses, and know how to defend a Ladies
honour.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
I hope your Grace knows him so well already, I
shall not need to tell you he is vain and foolish.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Aye you may call me what you please, but I will defend
your good name against the world; and so I take my leave
of your Grace, and of you my Lord Protector; I am like
wise glad to see your Lordship well.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
O Captain Bessus, I thank you, I would speak with
you anon.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: When you please, I will attend your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Madam, I will take my leave too.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Good Bacurius.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Madam what writes his Majesty to you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
O my Lord, the kindest words, I will keep them whilst
I live, here in my bosom, there is no art in them, they lie
disordered in this paper, just as hearty nature speaks them.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
And to me he writes what tears of joy he shed to
hear how you were grown in every virtues way, and yields
all thanks to me, for that dear care which I was bound to
have in training you, there is no Princess living that enjoys
a brother of that worth.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
My Lord, no maid longs more for anything,
And feels more heat and cold within her breast,
Than I do now, in hopes to see him.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Yet I wonder much
At this he writes, be brings along with him
A husband for you, that same Captive Prince,
And if he loves you as he makes a show,
He will allow you freedom in your choice.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
And so he will my Lord, I warrant you, he will
but offer and give me the power to take or leave.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Trust me, were I a Lady, I could not like that man
were bargained with before I choose him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
But I am not built on such wild humours, if I find
him worthy, he is not less because he is offered.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: It is true, he is not, would he would seem less.

sp.speaker: Gob.
Spa.
sp.p:
I know a Lady may, and more I fear
Another Lady will.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Would I might see him.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Why so you shall, my businesses are great,
I will attend you when it is his pleasure to see you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I thank you good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You will be ready Madam.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
I do beseech you Madam, send away
Your other women, and receive from me
A few sad words, which set against your joys
May make them shine the more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Sirs, leave me all.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
I kneel a stranger here to beg a thing
Unfit for me to ask, and you to grant,
It is such another strange ill-laid-request,
As if a beggar should entreat a King
To leave his Sceptre, and his Throne to him
And take his rags to wander over the world
Hungry and cold.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: That were a strange request.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: As ill is mine.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Then do not utter it.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Alas it is of that nature, that it must
Be uttered, I, and granted, or I die:
I am ashamed to speak it; but where life
Lies at the stake, I cannot think her woman
That will not take something unreasonably to hazard saving
of it: I shall seem a strange Petitioner, that wish all ill
to them I beg of, ere they give me ought; yet so I must:
I would you were not fair, nor wise, for in your ill consists
my good: if you were foolish, you would hear my prayer,
if foul, you had not power to hinder me: he would not
love you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: What is the meaning of it.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Nay, my request is more without the bounds
Of reason yet: for it is not in the power
Of you to do, what I would have you grant.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Why then it is idle, pray thee speak it out.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Your brother brings a Prince into this land,
Of such a noble shape, so sweet a grace,
So full of worth withal, that every maid
That looks upon him, gives away herself
To him forever; and for you to have
He brings him: and so mad is my demand
That I desire you not to have this man,
This excellent man, for whom you needs must die,
If you should miss him. I do now expect
You should laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Trust me I could weep rather, for I have found
In all thy words a strange disjointed sorrow.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: It is by me his own desire so, that you would not love him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
His own desire! why credit me Thalestris,
I am no common wooer: if he shall woo me, his worth may
be such, that I dare not swear I will not love him; but if he
will stay to have me woo him, I will promise thee, he may
keep all his graces to himself, and fear no ravishing from me.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
It is yet his own desire, but when he sees your face,
I fear it will not be; therefore I charge you as you have pity,
stop these tender ears from his enchanting voice, close up
those eyes, that you may neither catch a dart from him,
nor he from you; I charge you as you hope to live in quiet;
for when I am dead, for certain I will walk to visit him if he
break promise with me: for as fast as Oaths without a formal
Ceremony can make me, I am to him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Then be fearless;
For if he were a thing betwixt God and man,
I could gaze on him; if I knew it sin
To love him without passion: Dry your eyes,
I swear you shall enjoy him still for me,
I will not hinder you; but I perceive
You are not what you seem, rise, rise Thalestris,
If your right name be so.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Indeed it is not, Spaconia is my name; but I desire
not to be known to other.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Why, by me you shall not, I will never do you
wrong, what good I can, I will, think not my birth or education
such, that I should injure a stranger Virgin; you are
welcome hither, in company you wish to be commanded,
but when we are alone, I shall be ready to be your servant.

div2.stage: Enter three Men and a Woman.

sp.p: Come, come, run, run, run.
We shall out-go her.

One were better be hanged than carry out women
fiddling to these shows.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Is the King hard by?

You heard he with the Bottles said, he thought we
should come too late: What abundance of people here is?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: But what had he in those Bottles?
I know not.
Why, Ink goodman fool.
Ink, what to do?

Why the King look you, will many times call for
these Bottles, and break his mind to his friends.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Let us take our places, we shall have no room else.

The man told us he would walk on foot through the
people.
Aye marry did he.
Our shops are well looked to now.
'Slife, yonder is my Master, I think.
No it is not he.

div2.stage: Enter a man with two Citizens-wives.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p:
Lord how fine the fields be, what sweet living it is
in the Country!

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p:
Aye poor souls, God help them; they live as contentedly
as one of us.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p:
My husbands Cousin would have had me gone into
the Country last year, wert thou ever there?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Aye, poor souls, I was amongst them once.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: And what kind of creatures are they, for love of God?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Very good people, God help them.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p:
Wilt thou go down with me this Summer when I
am brought to bed?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Alas, it is no place for us.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why, pray thee?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Why you can have nothing there, there is nobody cries brooms.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: No truly, nor milk.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Nor milk, how do they?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: They are fain to milk themselves in the Country.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p:
Good Lord! but the people there, I think, will
be very dutiful to one of us.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p:
Aye God knows will they, and yet they do not greatly
care for our husbands.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p:
Do they not? Alas! In good faith I cannot blame
them: for we do not greatly care for them ourselves. Philip, I pray choose us a place:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: There is the best forsooth.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: By your leave good people a little.
What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
I pray you my friend, do not thrust my Mistress so,
she is with Child.

Let her look to herselfthen, has she not had showing
though yet? if she stay shouldering here, she may haps go
home with a cake in her belly.

How now, goodman squitter-breech, why do you lean
on me?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Because I will.
Will you Sir sauce-box?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p:
Look if one had not struck Philip, come hither
Philip, why did he strike thee?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: For leaning on him.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Why didst thou lean on him?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I did not think he would have struck me.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p:
As God save me la thou art as wild as a Buck, there is
no quarrel but thou art at one end or other of it.
It is at the first end then, for he will never stay the last.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Well slip-string, I shall meet with you.
When you will.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: I will give a crown to meet with you.
At a Bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p:
Aye you are full of your Roguery; but if I do meet you
it shall cost me a fall.
The King, the King, the King. Now, now, now, now.

div2.stage: Flourish. Enter Arb. Tigr. the two Kings and Mardonius.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God preserve your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I thank you all, now are my joys at full, when I
behold you safe, my loving Subjects; by you I grow, it is
your united love that lifts me to this height: all the account
that I can render you for all the love you have bestowed on
me, all your expenses to maintain my war, is but a little
word, you will imagine it is slender payment, yet it is such
a word, as is not to be bought but with your bloods, it is
Peace.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God preserve your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Now you may live securely in your Towns,
Your Children round about you; may sit
Under your Vines, and make the miseries
Of other Kingdoms a discourse for you,
And lend them sorrows; for yourselves, you may
Safely forget there are such things as tears,
And you may all whose good thoughts I have gained,
Hold me unworthy, where I think my life
A sacrifice too great to keep you thus
In such a calm estate.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God bless your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
See all good people, I have brought the man whose
very name you feared, a captive home; behold him, it is
Tigranes; in your heart sing songs of gladness, and deliverance.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Out upon him.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: How he looks.

sp.speaker: 3 Wom.
sp.p: Hang him, hang him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: These are sweet people.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Sir, you do me wrong, to render me a scorned
spectacle to common people.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
It was so far from me to mean it so: if I have ought
deserved, my loving Subjects, let me beg of you, not to revile
this Prince, in whom there dwells all worth of which
the name of a man is capable, valour beyond compare, the
terror of his name has stretched itself where ever there is
sun; and yet for you I fought with him single, and won him
too; I made his valour stoop, and brought that name
soared to so unbelieved a height, to fall beneath mine: this
inspired with all your loves, I did perform, and will for
your content, be ever ready for a greater work.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The Lord bless your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
So he has made me amends now with a speech in
commendation of himself: I would not be so vain-glorious.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
If there be anything in which I may
Do good to any creature, here speak out;
For I must leave you: and it troubles me,
That my occasions for the good of you,
Are such as call me from you: else, my joy
Would be to spend my days among you all.
You show your loves in these large multitudes
That come to meet me, I will pray for you,
Heaven prosper you, that you may know old years,
And live to see your children's children sit
At your boards with plenty: when there is
A want of anything, let it be known
To me, and I will be a Father to you:
God keep you all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God bless your Majesty, God bless your Majesty.
Come, shall we go? all is done.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Aye for God sake, I have not made a fire yet.
Away, away, all is done.
Content, farewell Philip.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p: Away you halter-sack you.
Philip will not fight, he is afraid of his face.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Aye marry am I afraid of my face.

Thou wouldst be Philip if thou sawest it in a glass; it
looks so like a Visor.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p:
you will be hanged sirrah: Come Philip walk before us
homewards; did not his Majesty say he had brought us
home Peas for all our money?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Yes marry did he.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.p:
They are the first I heard of this year by my troth, I
longed for some of them: did he not say we should have some?

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p:
Yes, and so we shall anon I warrant you have every
one a peck brought home to our houses.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: My Sister take it ill?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Not very ill,
Something unkindly she does take it Sir to have
Her Husband chosen to her hands.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why Gobrias let her, I must have her know, my will
and not her own must govern her: what will she marry with
some slave at home?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
O she is far from any stubbornness, you much mistake
her, and no doubt will like where you would have her, but
when you behold her, you will be loath to part with such a
jewel.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
To part with her? why Gobrias, art thou mad? she
is my Sister.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Sir, I know she is: but it were pity to make poor
our Land, with such a beauty to enrich another.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Pish will she have him?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: I do hope she will not, I think she will Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Were she my Father and my Mother too, and all the
names for which we think folks friends, she should be forced
to have him when I know it is sit: I will not hear her say
she is loath.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Heaven bring my purpose luckily to pass, you know
it is just, she will not need constraint she loves you so.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How does she love me, speak?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
She loves you more than people love their health,
that live by labour; more than I could love a man that died
for me, if he could live again.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: She is not like her mother then.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
O no, when you were in Armenia,
I durst not let her know when you were hurt:
For at the first on every little scratch,
She kept her Chamber, wept, and could not eat,
Till you were well, and many times the news
Was so long coming, that before we heard
She was as near her death, as you your health.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Alas poor soul, but yet she must be ruled;
I know not how I shall requite her well.
I long to see her, have you sent for her,
To tell her I am ready?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir I have.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Sir, here is the Armenian King.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: He is welcome.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p:
And the Queen mother, and the Princess wait
without.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Good Gobrias bring them in.
Tigranes, you will think you are arrived
in a strange Land, where Mothers cast to poison
Their only Sons; think you you shall be safe?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Too safe I am Sir.

div2.stage: Enter Gobrias, Arane, Panthea, Spaconia, Bacurius, Mardonius and Bessus, and two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p:
As low as this I bow to you, and would
As low as is my grave, to show a mind
Thankful for all your mercies.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
O stand up,
And let me kneel, the light will be ashamed
To see observance done to me by you.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: You are my King.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
You are my Mother, rise;
As far be all your faults from your own soul,
As from my memory; then you shall be
As white as innocence herself.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p:
I came
Only to show my duty, and acknowledge
My sorrows for my sins; longer to stay
Were but to draw eyes more attentively
Upon my shame, that power that kept you safe
From me, preserve you still.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Your own desires shall be your guide.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Now let me die, since I have seen my Lord the King
Return in safety, I have seen all good that life
Can show me; I have never another wish
For Heaven to grant, nor were it fit I should;
For I am bound to spend my age to come,
In giving thanks that this was granted me.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Why does not your Majesty speak?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: To the Princess.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Alas Sir, I am fearful, you do look
On me, as if I were some loathed thing
That you were finding out a way to shun.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir, you should speak to her.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I know I am unworthy, yet not ill armed, with which
innocence here I will kneel, till I am one with earth, but I
will gain some words and kindness from you.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Will you speak Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Speak, am I what I was?
What art thou that dost creep into my breast,
And darest not see my face? show forth thyself:
I feel a pair of fiery wings displayed
Hither, from hence; you shall not tarry there,
Up, and be gone, if thou beest Love be gone:
Or I will tear thee from my wounded breast,
Pull thy loved Down away, and with thy Quill
By this right arm drawn from thy wonted wing,
Write to thy laughing Mother in thy blood,
That you are powers belied, and all your darts
Are to be blown away, by men resolved,
Like dust; I know thou fearest my words, away.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
O misery! why should he be so slow?
There can no falsehood come of loving her;
Though I have given my faith; she is a thing
Both to be loved and served beyond my faith:
I would he would present me to her quickly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Will you not speak at all? are you so far
From kind words? yet to save my modesty,
That must talk till you answer, do not stand
As you were dumb, say something, though it be
Poisoned with anger, that it may strike me dead.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Have you no life at all? for man-hood sake
Let her not kneel, and talk neglected thus;
A tree would find a tongue to answer her,
Did she but give it such a loved respect.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
You mean this Lady: list her from the earth; why
do you let her kneel so long? Alas, Madam, your beauty
uses to command, and not to beg. What is your suit to
me? it shall be granted, yet the time is short, and my affairs
are great: but where is my Sister? I bade she should be brought

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, is he mad?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Gobrias, where is she?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Where is she man?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Who, Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Who, hast thou forgot my Sister?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Your Sister, Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Your Sister, Sir? someone that hath a wit, answer,
where is she?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Do you not see her there?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: There, where?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'slight, there, are you blind?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Which do you mean, that little one?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
No Sir? why, do you mock me? I can see
No other here, but that petitioning Lady.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: That is she.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir, it is she.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It is false.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Is it?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
As hell, by Heaven, as false as hell,
My Sister: is she dead? if it be so,
Speak boldly to me; for I am a man,
And dare not quarrel with Divinity;
And do not think to cozen me with this:
I see you all are mute and stand amazed,
Fearful to answer me; it is too true,
A decreed instant cuts off every life,
For which to mourn, is to repine; she died
A Virgin, though more innocent than sheep,
As clear as herown eyes, and blessedness
Eternal waits upon her where she is:
I know she could not make a wish to change
Her state for new, and you shall see me bear
My crosses like a man; we all must die,
And she hath taught us how.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Do not mistake,
And vex yourselffor nothing; for her death
Is a long life off, I hope: It is she,
And if my speech deserve not faith, lay death
Upon me, and my latest words shall force
A credit from you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Which, good Gobrias? that Lady dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
That Lady Sir,
She is your Sister, and she is your Sister
That loves you so, it is she for whom I weep,
To see you use her thus.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Pish, this is tedious,
I cannot hold, I must present myself,
And yet the sight of my Spaconia
Touches me, as a sudden thunder-clap
Does one that is about to sin.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Away,
No more of this; here I pronounce him Traitor,
The direct plotter of my death, that names
Or thinks her for my Sister, it is a lie,
The most malicious of the world, invented
To mad your King; he that will say so next,
Let him draw out his sword and sheath it here,
It is a sin fully as pardonable:
She is no kin to me, nor shall she be;
If she were ever, I create her none:
And which of you can question this? My power
Is like the Sea, that is to be obeyed,
And not disputed with: I have decreed her
As far from having part of blood with me,
As the naked Indians; come and answer me,
He that is boldest now; is that my Sister?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O this is fine.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
No marry, she is not, if it please your Majesty, I
never thought she was, she is nothing like you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: No it is true, she is not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thou shouldst be hanged.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Sir, I will speak but once; by the same power
You make my blood a stranger unto yours,
You may command me dead, and so much love
A stranger may importune, pray you do;
If this request appear too much to grant,
Adopt me of some other Family,
By your unquestioned word; else I shall live
Like sinful issues that are left in streets
By their regardless Mothers, and no name
Will be found for me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I will hear no more,
Why should there be such music in a voice,
And sin for me to hear it? All the world
May take delight in this, and it is damnation
For me to do so: You are fair and wise
And virtuous I think, and he is blessed
That is so near you as my brother is;
But you are naught to me but a disease;
Continual torment without hope of ease;
Such an ungodly sickness I have got,
That he that undertakes my cure, must first
Overthrow Divinity, all moral Laws,
And leave mankind as unconfined as beasts,
Allowing them to do all actions
As freely as they drink when they desire.
Let me not hear you speak again; yet see
I shall but languish for the want of that,
The having which, would kill me: No man here
Offer to speak for her; for I consider
As much as you can say; I will not toil
My body and my mind too, rest thou there,
Here is one within will labour for you both.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I would I were past speaking.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Fear not Madam,
The King will alter, it is some sudden rage,
And you shall see it end some other way.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Pray heaven it do.

sp.speaker: Tig.
sp.p:
Though she to whom I swore, be here, I cannot
Stifle my passion longer; if my father
Should rise again disquieted with this,
And charge me to forbear, yet it would out.
Madam, a stranger, and a prisoner begs
To be bid welcome.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You are welcome, Sir,
I think, but if you be not, it is past me
To make you so: for I am here a stranger,
Greater than you; we know from whence you come,
But I appear a lost thing, and by whom
Is yet uncertain, found here in the Court,
And only suffered to walk up and down,
As one not worth the owning.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
O, I fear
Tigranes will be caught, he looks, methinks,
As he would change his eyes with her; some help
There is above for me, I hope.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Why do you turn away, and weep so fast,
And utter things that misbecome your looks,
Can you want owning?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: O it is certain so.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Acknowledge yourselfmine.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: And then see if you want an owner.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: They are talking.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Nations shall own you for their Queen.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Tigranes, art not thou my prisoner?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And who is this?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: She is your Sister.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: She is so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is she so again? that is well.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And then how dare you offer to change words with her?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Dare do it! Why? you brought me hither Sir,
To that intent.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Perhaps I told you so,
If I had sworn it, had you so much folly
To credit it? The least word that she speaks
Is worth a life; rule your disordered tongue,
Or I will temper it.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Blessed be the breath.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Temper my tongue! such incivilities
As these, no barbarous people ever knew:
You break the laws of Nature, and of Nations,
You talk to me as if I were a prisoner
For theft: my tongue be tempered? I must speak
If thunder check me, and I will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: You will?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Alas my fortune.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Do not fear his frown, dear Madam, hear me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Fear not my frown? but that it were base in me
To fight with one I know I can overcome,
Again thou shouldest be conquered by me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
He has one ransom with him already; methinks
It were good to fight double, or quit.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Away with him to prison: Now Sir, see
If my frown be regardless; Why delay you?
Seize him Bacurius, you shall know my word
Sweeps like a wind, and all it grapples with,
Are as the chaff before it.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Touch me not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Help there.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: It is in vain to struggle.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: You must be forced.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Sir, you must pardon us, we must obey.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why do you dally there? drag him away
By anything.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Come Sir.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Justice, thou oughtest to give me strength enough
To shake all these off; This is tyranny,
Arbaces, sutler than the burning Bulls,
Or that famed Titans bed. Thou mightst as well
Search in the deep of Winter through the snow
For half starved people, to bring home with thee,
To show them fire, and send them back again,
As use me thus.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Let him be close, Bacurius.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
I never rejoiced at any ill to him,
But this imprisonment: what shall become
Of me forsaken?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
You will not let your Sister
Depart thus discontented from you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
By no means Gobrias, I have done her wrong,
And made myselfbelieve much of myself,
That is not in me: You did kneel to me,
Whilst I stood stubborn and regardless by,
And like a god incensed, gave no ear
To all your prayers: behold, I kneel to you,
Show a contempt as large as was my own,
And I will suffer it, yet at the last forgive me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
O you wrong me more in this,
Than in your rage you did: you mock me now.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Never forgive me then, which is the worst
Can happen to me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
If you be in earnest,
Stand up and give me but a gentle look,
And two kind words, and I shall be in heaven.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Rise you then to hear; I acknowledge thee
My hope, the only jewel of my life,
The best of Sisters, dearer than my breath,
A happiness as high as I could think;
And when my actions call thee otherwise,
Perdition light upon me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
This is better
Than if you had not frowned, it comes to me,
Like mercy at the block, and when I leave
To serve you with my life, your curse be with me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Then thus I do salute thee, and again,
To make this knot the stronger, Paradise
Is there: It may be you are yet in doubt,
This third kiss blots it out, I wade in sin,
And foolishly entice myselfalong;
Take her away, see her a prisoner
In her own chamber closely, Gobrias.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Alas Sir, why?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I must not stay the answer, do it.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: No more, do it I say.

sp.speaker: Mard.
sp.p: This is better and better.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Yet hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I will not hear you speak,
Away with her, let no man think to speak
For such a creature; for she is a witch,
A prisoner, and a Traitor.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Madam, this office grieves me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Nay, it is well the king is pleased with it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Bessus, go you along too with her; I will prove
All this that I have said, if I may live
So long; but I am desperately sick,
For she has given me poison in a kiss;
She had it betwixt her lips, and with her eyes
She witches people: go without a word.
Why should you that have made me stand in war
Like fate itself, cutting what threads I pleased,
Decree such an unworthy end of me,
And all my glories? What am I, alas,
That you oppose me? if my secret thoughts
Have ever harboured swellings against you,
They could not hurt you, and it is in you
To give me sorrow, that will render me
Apt to receive your mercy; rather so,
Let it be rather so, than punish me
With such unmanly sins: Incest is in me
Dwelling already, and it must be holy
That pulls it thence, where art Mardonius?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I pray thee bear me, if thou canst,
Am I not grown a strange weight?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: As you were.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: No heavier?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why, my legs
Refuse to bear my body; O Mardonius,
Thou hast in field beheld me, when thou knowest
I could have gone, though I could never run.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And so I shall again.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: O no, it is past.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray you go rest yourself.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Wilt thou hereafter when they talk of me,
As thou shalt hear nothing but infamy,
Remember some of those things?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes I will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I pray thee do: for thou shalt never see me so again.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
They talk of fame, I have gotten it in the wars;
and will afford any man a reasonable penny-worth: some
will say, they could be content to have it, but that it is to
be achieved with danger; but my opinion is otherwise:
for if I might stand still in Cannon proof, and have fame
fall upon me, I would refuse it: my reputation came principally
by thinking to run away, which nobody knows
but Mardonius, and I think he conceals it to anger me.
Before I went to the wars, I came to the Town a young
fellow, without means or parts to deserve friends; and
my empty guts persuaded me to lie, and abuse people for
my meat, which I did, and they beat me: then would I
fast two days, till my hunger cried out on me, rail still,
then methought I had a monstrous stomach to abuse them
again, and did it. I, this state I continued till they hung
me up by the heels, and beat me with hazel sticks, as if they
would have baked me, and have cozened some body with me
for Venison: After this I railed, and eat quietly: for the
whole Kingdom took notice of me for a baffled whipped fellow,
and what I said was remembered in mirth but never in
anger, of which I was glad; I would it were at that pass
again. After this, heaven calls an Aunt of mine, that left
two hundred pound in a cousins hand for me, who taking me
to be a gallant young spirit, raised a company for me with
the money and sent me into Armenia with them: Away I
would have run from them, but that I could get no company,
and alone I durst not run. I was never at battle
but once, and there I was running, but Mardonius cudgeled
me; yet I got loose at last, but was so afraid, that I saw no
more than my shoulders do, but fled with my whole company
amongst my Enemies, and overthrew them: Now the
report of my valour is come over before me, and they say I
was a raw young fellow, but now I am improved, a Plague
on their eloquence, it will cost me many a beating; And
Mardonius might help this too, if he would; for now they
think to get honour on me, and all the men I have abused
call me freshly worthily, as they call it by the way of challenge.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p: Good morrow, Captain Bessus.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Good morrow Sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p: I come to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: You are very welcome.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p:
From one that holds himself wronged by you
some three years since: your worth he says is famed, and he
doth nothing doubt but you will do him right, as beseems a
soldier.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: A pox on them, so they cry all.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p:
And a slight note I have about me for you, for
the delivery of which you must excuse me; it is an office
that friendship calls upon me to do, and no way offensive to
you; since I desire but right on both sides.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: It is a challenge Sir, is it not?

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p: It is an inviting to the field.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
An inviting? O Sir your Mercy, what a Complement
he delivers it with? he might as agreeable to my nature
present me poison with such a speech: um um um reputation,
um um um call you to account, um um um forced to this,
um um um with my Sword, um um um like a Gentleman,
um um um dear to me, um um um satisfaction: It is very
well Sir, I do accept it, but he must await an answer this
thirteen weeks.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p:
Why Sir, he would be glad to wipe off his stain
as soon as he could.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Sir upon my credit I am already engaged to two hundred,
and twelve, all which must have their stains wiped off,
if that be the word, before him.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p:
Sir, if you be truly engaged but to one, he shall
stay a competent time.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Upon my faith Sir, to two hundred and twelve, and
I have a spent body, too much bruised in battle, so that I
cannot fight, I must be plain, above three combats a day:
All the kindness I can show him, is to set him resolvedly in
my roll, the two hundred and thirteenth man, which is
something, for I tell you, I think there will be more after
him, than before him, I think so; pray you commend me to
him, and tell him this.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p: I will Sir, good morrow to you.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Good morrow good Sir. Certainly my safest way
were to print myselfa coward, with a discovery how I
came by my credit, and clap it upon every post; I have received
above thirty challenges within this two hours, marry
all but the first I put off with engagement, and by good fortune,
the first is no madder of fighting than I, so that that is referred,
the place where it must be ended, is four days journey
off, and our arbitrators are these: He has chosen a Gentleman
in travel, and I have a special friend with a quartan
ague, like to hold him this five years, for mine: and when
his man comes home, we are to expect my friends health:
If they would find me challenges thus thick, as long as I
lived, I would have no other living; I can make seven shillings
a day of the paper to the Grocers: yet I learn nothing by
all these but a little skill in comparing of stiles. I do find
evidently, that there is some one Scrivener in this Town,
that has a great hand in writing of Challenges, for they
are all of a cut, and six of them in a hand; and they all end,
my reputation is dear to me, and I must require satisfaction:
Who is there? more paper I hope, no, it is my Lord Bacurius,
I fear all is not well betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Now Captain Bessus, I come about a frivolous matter,
caused by as idle a report: you know you were a coward.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Very right.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: And wronged me.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: True my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
But now people will call you valiant, desertlessly I
think, yet for their satisfaction, I will have you fight with me.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: O my good Lord, my deep Engagements.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Tell not me of your Engagements, Captain Bessus,
it is not to be put off with an excuse: for my own part, I
am none of the multitude that believe your conversion from
Coward.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
My Lord, I seek not Quarrels, and this belongs not
to me, I am not to maintain it.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Who then pray?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Bessus the Coward wronged you.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: And shall Bessus the Valiant, maintain what Bessus the Coward did?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
I pray thee leave these cheating tricks, I swear thou
shalt fight with me, or thou shalt be beaten extremely,
and kicked.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Since you provoke me thus far, my Lord, I will
fight with you, and by my Sword it shall cost me twenty
pound, but I will have my Leg well a week sooner purposely.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Your Leg? Why, what ails your Leg? I will do a
cure on you, stand up.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: My Lord, this is not Noble in you.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
What dost thou with such a phrase in thy mouth?
I will kick thee out of all good words before I leave thee.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
My Lord, I take this as a punishment for the offence
I did when I was a Coward.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
When thou wert? Confess thyself a Coward still,
or by this light, I will beat thee into Sponge.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Why I am one.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Are you so Sir? And why do you wear a Sword
then? Come unbuckle.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Unbuckle I say, and give it me, or as I live, thy
head will ache extremely.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
It is a pretty Hilt, and if your Lordship take an
affection to it, with all my heart I present it to you for a
New-years gift.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I thank you very heartily, sweet Captain, farewell.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
One word more, I beseech your Lordship to render
me my knife again.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Marry by all means Captain; cherish yourselfwith
it, and eat hard, good Captain; we cannot tell whether we
shall have any more such: Adieu dear Captain.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
I will make better use of this, than of my Sword:
A base spirit has this vantage of a brave one, it keeps always
at a stay, nothing brings it down, not beating. I
remember I promised the King in a great Audience, that I
would make my backbiters eat my sword to a knife; how
to get another sword I know not, nor know any means left
for me to maintain my credit, but impudence: therefore I
will out-swear him and all his followers, that this is all
that is left uneaten of my sword.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I will move the King, he is most strangely altered;
I guess the cause I fear too right, Heaven has some secret
end in it, and it is a scourge no question justly laid upon
him: he has followed me through twenty Rooms; and
ever when I stay to wait his command, he blushes like a Girl,
and looks upon me, as if modesty kept in his business: so
turns away from me, but if I go on, he follows me again.

See, here he is. I do not use this, yet I know not how,
I cannot choose but weep to see him; his very Enemies I
think, whose wounds have bred his fame, if they should
see him now, would find tears in their eyes.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I cannot utter it, why should I keep
A breast to harbour thoughts? I dare not speak.
Darkness is in my bosom, and there lie
A thousand thoughts that cannot brook the light:
How wilt thou vex them when this deed is done,
Conscience, that art afraid to let me name it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why very well Mardonius, how dost thou do?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Better than you I fear.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I hope thou art; for to be plain with thee,
Thou art in Hell else, secret scorching flames
That far transcend earthly material fires
Are crept into me, and there is no cure.
Is it not strange Mardonius, there is no cure?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sir, either I mistake, or there is something hid
That you would utter to me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: So there is, but yet I cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Out with it Sir, if it be dangerous, I will not
