shrink to do you service, I shall not esteem my life a weightier
matter than indeed it is, I know it is subject to more
chances than it has hours, and I were better lose it in my
Kings cause, than with an ague, or a fall, or sleeping,
to a Thief; as all these are probable enough: let me but
know what I shall do for you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
It will not out: were you with Gobrias,
And bad him give my Sister all content
The place affords, and give her leave to send
And speak to whom she please?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I was.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
And did you to Bacurius say as much
About Tigranes?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: That all my business.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
O say not so,
You had an answer of this before;
Besides I think this business might
Be uttered more carelessly.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Come thou shalt have it out, I do beseech thee
By all the love thou hast professed to me,
To see my Sister from me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, and what?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: That is all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That strange, I shall say nothing to her?

sp.speaker: Arb.
Mar.
sp.p: But what shall I make her understand?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: O Mardonius, for that I must be pardoned.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You may, but I can only see her then.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
It is true;
Bear her this Ring then, and
One more advice, thou shalt speak to her:
Tell her I do love My kindred all: wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is there no more?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
O yes and her the best;
Better than any Brother loves his Sister: That is all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Methinks this need not have been delivered with
such a caution; I will do it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
There is more yet,
Wilt thou be faithful to me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sir, if I take upon me to deliver it, after I hear it,
I will pass through fire to do it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I love her better than a Brother ought;
Dost thou conceive me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I hope you do not Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
No, thou art dull, kneel down before her,
And never rise again, till she will love me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, I think she does.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
But better than she does, another way;
As wives love Husbands.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Why, I think there are few Wives that love their
Husbands better than she does you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Thou wilt not understand me: is it fit
This should be uttered plainly? take it then
Naked as it is: I would desire her love
Lasciviously, lewdly, incestuously,
To do a sin that needs must damn us both;
And thee too: dost thou understand me now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Yes, there is your Ring again; what have I done
Dishonestly in my whole life, name it,
That you should put so base a business to me?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Didst thou not tell me thou wouldst do it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Yes; if I undertook it, but if all
My hairs were lives, I would not be engaged
In such a case to save my last life.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
O guilt! ha how poor and weak a thing art thou?
This man that is my servant, whom my breath
Might blow upon the world, might beat me here
Having this cause, whilst I pressed down with sin
Could not resist him: hear Mardonius,
It was a motion misbeseeming man,
And I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Heaven grant you may be so: you must understand,
nothing that you can utter, can remove my love
and service from my Prince. But otherwise, I think I
shall not love you more. For you are sinful, and if you do
this crime, you ought to have no Laws. For after this, it
will be great injustice in you to punish any offender for any
crime. For myselfI find my heart too big: I feel I have
not patience to look on whilst you run these forbidden
courses. Means I have none but your favour, and I am
rather glad that I shall lose them both together, than keep
them with such conditions; I shall find a dwelling amongst
some people, where though our Garments perhaps be courser,
we shall be richer far within, and harbour no such vices
in them: the Gods preserve you, and mend.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Mardonius, stay Mardonius, for though
My present state requires nothing but knaves
To be about me, such as are prepared
For every wicked act, yet who does know
But that my loathed Fate may turn about,
And I have use for honest men again?
I hope I may, I prithee leave me not.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: If it please your Majesty, there is the knife.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What knife?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: The Sword is eaten.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Away you fool, the King is serious,
And cannot now admit your vanities.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Vanities! I am no honest man, if my enemies have
not brought it to this, what, do you think I lie?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: No, no, it is well Bessus, it is very well I amglad of it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
If your enemies brought it to this, your enemies
are Cutlers, come leave the King.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Why, may not valour approach him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Yes, but he has affairs, depart, or I shall be
something unmannerly with you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
No, let him stay Mardonius, let him stay,
I have occasion with him very weighty,
And I can spare you now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why I can spare you now.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Mardonius give way to these State affairs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed you are fitter for this present purpose.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Bessus, I should employ thee, wilt thou do it?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Do it for you? by this Air I will do anything without
exception, be it a good, bad, or indifferent thing.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Do not swear.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: By this light but I will, anything whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
But I shall name the thing,
Thy Conscience will not suffer thee to do.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I would fain hear that thing.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why I would have thee get my Sister for me?
Thou understandest me, in a wicked manner.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
O you would have a bout with her?
I will do it, I will do it, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Wilt thou, dost thou make no more of it?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
More? no, why is there anything else? if there
be, it shall be done too.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Hast thou no greater sense of such a sin?
Thou art too wicked for my company,
Though I have hell within me, thou mayst yet
Corrupt me further: pray thee answer me,
How do I show to thee after this motion?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Why your Majesty looks as well in my opinion, as
ever you did since you were born.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
But thou appearest to me after thy grant,
The ugliest, loathed detestable thing
That I ever met with. Thou hast eyes
Like the flames of Sulphur, which methinks do dart
Infection on me, and thou hast a mouth
Enough to take me in where there do stand
Four rows of Iron Teeth.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
I feel no such thing, but it is no matter how I look,
I will do my business as well as they that look better, and
when this is despatched, if you have a mind to your Mother,
tell me, and yon shall see I will set it hard.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
My Mother! Heaven forgive me to hear this,
I am inspired with horror: now I hate thee
Worse than my sin, which if I could come by
Should suffer death Eternal never to rise
In any breast again. Know I will die
Languishing mad, as I resolve, I shall,
Ere I will deal by such an instrument:
Thou art too sinful to employ in this;
Out of the World, away.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Hung round with Curses, take thy fearful flight
Into the Deserts, where amongst all the Monsters
If thou findest one so beastly as thyself,
Thou shalt be held as innocent.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
If there were no such instruments as thou,
We Kings could never act such wicked deeds:
Seek out a man that mocks Divinity,
That breaks each precept both of God and man,
And nature's too, and does it without lust,
Merely because it is a law, and good,
And live with him: for him thou canst not spoil.
Away I say, I will not do this sin.
I will press it here, till it do break my breast,
It heaves to get out, but thou art a sin,
And spite of torture I will keep thee in.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Have you written Madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Yes, good Gobrias.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
And with a kindness, and such winning words
As may provoke him, at one instant feel
His double fault, your wrong, and his own rashness?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I have sent words enough, if words may win him
From his displeasure; and such words I hope,
As shall gain much upon his goodness, Gobrias.
Yet fearing they are many, and a woman's,
A poor belief may follow, I have woven
As many truths within them to speak for me,
That if he be but gracious, and receive them -

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Good Lady be not fearful, though he should not
Give you your present end in this, believe it,
You shall feel, if your virtue can induce you
To labour on it, this tempest which I know,
Is but a poor proof against your patience:
All those contents, your spirit will arrive at,
Newer and sweeter to you; your Royal brother,
When he shall once collect himself, and see
How far he has been asunder from himself;
What a mere stranger to his golden temper:
Must from those roots of virtue, never dying,
Though somewhat stopped with humour, shoot again
Into a thousand glories, bearing his fair-branches
High as our hopes can look at, straight as justice,
Laden with ripe contents; he loves you dearly,
I know it, and I hope I need not farther
Win you to understand it.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I believe it.
But howsoever, I am sure I love him dearly:
So dearly, that if anything I write
For my enlarging should beget his anger,
Heaven be a witness with me and my faith,
I had rather live entombed here.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
You shall not feel a worse stroke than your grief,
I am sorry it is so sharp, I kiss your hand,
And this night will deliver this true story,
With this hand to your Brother.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Peace go with you, you are a good man.
My Spaconia, why are you ever sad thus?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: O dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Prithee discover not a way to sadness,
Nearer than I have in me, our two sorrows
Work like two eager Hawks, who shall get highest;
How shall I lessen thine? for mine I fear
Is easier known than cured.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Heaven comfort both,
And give you happy ends, however I
Fall in my stubborn fortunes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
This but teaches
How to be more familiar with our sorrows,
That are too much our masters: good Spaconia
How shall I do you service?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Noblest Lady,
You make me more a slave still to your goodness,
And only live to purchase thanks to pay you,
For that is all the business of my life: now
I will be bold, since you will have it so,
To ask a noble favour of you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Speak it, it is yours, for from so sweet a virtue,
No ill demand has issue.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Then ever virtuous, let me beg your will
In helping me to see the Prince Tigranes,
With whom I am equal prisoner, if not more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Reserve me to a greater end Spaconia;
Bacurius cannot want so much good manners
As to deny your gentle visitation,
Though you came only with your own command.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
I know they will deny me gracious Madam,
Being a stranger, and so little famed,
So utter empty of those excellencies
That tame Authority; but in you sweet Lady,
All these are natural; beside, a power
Derived immediate from your Royal brother,
Whose least word in you may command the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
More than my word Spaconia, you shall carry,
For fear it fail you.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Dare you trust a Token?
Madam I fear I am grown too bold a beggar.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You are a pretty one, and trust me Lady
It joys me, I shall do a good to you,
Though to myselfI never shall be happy:
Here, take this Ring, and from me as a Token
Deliver it; I think they will not stay you:
So all your own desires go with you Lady.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: And sweet peace to your Grace.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Pray Heaven I find it.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Fool that I am, I have undone myself,
And with my own hand turned my fortune round,
That was a fair one: I have childishly
Played with my hope so long, till I have broke it,
And now too late I mourn for it; O Spaconia!
Thou hast found an even way to thy revenge now,
Why didst thou follow me like a faint shadow,
To wither my desires? But wretched fool,
Why did I plant thee betwixt the Sun and me,
To make me freeze thus? Why did I prefer her
To the fair Princess? O thou fool, thou fool,
Thou family of fools, live like a slave still,
And in thee bear thine own hell and thy torment,
Thou hast deserved: Couldst thou find no Lady
But she that has thy hopes to put her to,
And hazard all thy peace? None to abuse,
But she that loved thee ever? poor Spaconia,
And so much loved thee, that in honesty
And honour thou art bound to meet her virtues:
She that forgot the greatness of her grief
And miseries, that must follow such mad passions,
Endless and wild as women; she that for thee
And with thee left her liberty, her name,
And Country, you have paid me equal, Heavens,
And sent my own rod to correct me with;
A woman: for inconstancy I will suffer,
Lay it on justice, till my soul melt in me
For my unmanly, beastly, sudden doting
Upon a new face: after all my oaths
Many and strange ones,
I feel my old fire flame again and burn
So strong and violent, that should I see her
Again, the grief and that would kill me.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Lady, your token I acknowledge, you may pass;
There is the King.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: I thank your Lordship for it.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
She comes, she comes, shame hide me ever from her,
Would I were buried, or so far removed
Light might not find me out, I dare not see her.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Nay never hide yourself; or were you hid
Where earth hides all her riches, near her Centre;
My wrongs without more day would light me to you:
I must speak ere I die; were all your greatness
Doubled upon you, you are a perjured man,
And only mighty in your wickedness
Of wronging women. Thou art false, false Prince;
I live to see it, poor Spaconia lives
To tell thee thou art false; and then no more;
She lives to tell thee thou art more unconstant,
Than all ill women ever were together.
Thy faith is firm as raging over-flows,
That no bank can command; as lasting
As boys' gay bubbles, blown in the Air and broken:
The wind is fixed to thee: and sooner shall
The beaten Mariner with his shrill whistle
Calm the loud murmur of the troubled main,
And strike it smooth again; than thy soul fall
To have peace in love with any: Thou art all
That all good men must hate; and if thy story
Shall tell succeeding ages what thou wert,
O let it spare me in it, lest true lovers
In pity of my wrong, burn thy black Legend,
And with their curses, shake thy sleeping ashes.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: O! O!

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
The destinies, I hope, have pointed out
Our ends, that thou mayest die for love,
Though not for me; for this assure thyself,
The Princess hates thee deadly, and will sooner
Be won to marry with a Bull, and safer
Than such a beast as thou art: I have struck,
I fear, too deep; beshrew me for it; Sir,
This sorrow works me like a cunning friendship,
Into the same piece with it; it is ashamed,
Alas, I have been too rugged: Dear my Lord,
I am sorry I have spoken anything,
Indeed I am, that may add more restraint
To that too much you have: good Sir, be pleased
To think it was a fault of love, not malice;
And do as I will do, forgive it Prince.
I do, and can forgive the greatest sins
To me you can repent of; pray believe.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: O my Spaconia! O thou virtuous woman!

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Nay, more, the King Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Have you been careful of our noble Prisoner,
That he want nothing fitting for his greatness?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I hope his grace will quit me for my care Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It is well, royal Tigranes, health.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
More than the strictness of this place can give Sir,
I offer back again to great Arbaces.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
We thank you worthy Prince, and pray excuse us,
We have not seen you since your being here,
I hope your noble usage has been equal
With your own person: your imprisonment,
If it be any, I dare say is easy,
And shall not last two days.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
Arb.
sp.p: What Lady is that? Bacurius?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: One of the Princess women, Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I feared it, why comes she hither?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: To speak with the Prince Tigranes.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: From whom, Bacurius?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: From the Princess, Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I knew I had seen her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
His fit begins to take him now again,
It is a strange Fever, and it will shake us all anon, I fear,
Would he were well cured of this raging folly:
Give me the wars, where men are mad, and may talk
what they list, and held the bravest fellows; This pelting
prating peace is good for nothing: drinking is a virtue to it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I see there is truth in no man, nor obedience,
But for his own ends, why did you let her in?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
It was your own command to barr none from him,
Besides, the Princess sent her ring Sir, for my warrant.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
A token to Tigranes, did she not?
Sir tell truth.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
I do not use to lie Sir,
It is no way I eat or live by, and I think,
This is no token Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
This combat has undone him: if he had been well
beaten, he had been temperate; I shall never see him handsome
again, till he have a Horse-man's staff yoked thorough
his shoulders, or an arm broken with a bullet.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I am trifled with.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I know it, as I know thee to be false.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now the clap comes.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
You never knew me so, Sir I dare speak it,
And durst a worse man tell me, though my better

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It is well said, by my soul.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Sirrah, you answer as you had no life.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: That I fear Sir to lose nobly.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I say Sir, once again.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
You may say what yon please, Sir,
Would I might do so.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I will, Sir, and say openly, this woman carries letters,
By my life I know she carries letters, this woman does it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Would Bessus were here to take her aside and search
her, He would quickly tell you what she carried Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I have found it out, this woman carries letters.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
If this hold, it will be an ill world for Bawds,
Chamber-maids and Post boys, I thank heaven I have none
but his letters patents, things of his own indicting.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Prince, this cunning cannot do it.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Do, What Sir? I reach you not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It shall not serve your turn, Prince.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Serve my turn Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Aye Sir, it shall not serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Be plainer, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
This woman shall carry no more letters back to your
Love Panthea, by Heaven she shall not, I say she shall not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This would make a Saint swear like a soldier.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
This beats me more, King, than the blows
you gave me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Take them away both, and together let them prisoners
be, strictly and closely kept, or Sirrah, your life shall answer
it, and let nobody speak with them hereafter.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Well, I am subject to you,
And must endure these passions:
This is the imprisonment I have looked for always.
And the dearer place I would choose.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, you have done well now.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Dare you reprove it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: You must be crossing me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I have no letters Sir to anger you,
But a dry sonnet of my Corporals
To an old Sutler's wife, and that I will burn, Sir.
It is like to prove a fine age for the Ignorant.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
How darest thou so often forfeit thy life?
Thou knowest it is in my power to take it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Yes, and I know you would not, or if you do, you will
miss it quickly.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Who shall tell you of these childish follies
When I am dead? who shall put to his power
To draw those virtues out of a flood of humours,
When they are drowned, and make them shine again?
No, cut my head off:
Then you may talk, and be believed, and grow worse,
And have your too self-glorious temper rot
Into a deep sleep, and the Kingdom with you,
Till foreign swords be in your throats, and slaughter
Be every where about you like your flatterers.
Do, kill me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Prithee be tamer, good Mardonius,
Thou knowest I love thee, nay I honour thee,
Believe it good old Soldier, I am thine;
But I am racked clean from myself, bear with me,
Wilt thou bear with me my Mardonius?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
There comes a good man, love him too, he is temperate,
You may live to have need of such a virtue,
Rage is not still in fashion.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Welcome good Gobrias.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: My service and this letter to your Grace.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
From the rich Mine of virtue and beauty,
Your mournful Sister.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: She is in prison, Gobrias, is she not?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
She is Sir, till your pleasure to enlarge her,
Which on my knees I beg. O it is not fit,
That all the sweetness of the world in one,
The youth and virtue that would tame wild Tigers,
And wilder people, that have known no manners,
Should live thus cloistered up; for your loves sake,
If there be any in that noble heart,
To her a wretched Lady, and forlorn,
Or for her love to you, which is as much
As nature and obedience ever gave,
Have pity on her beauties.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Pray thee stand up; It is true, she is too fair,
And all these commendations but her own,
Would thou hadst never so commended her,
Or I never lived to have heard it Gobrias;
If thou but knowest the wrong her beauty does her,
Thou wouldst in pity of her be a liar,
Thy ignorance has drawn me wretched man,
Whither myselfnor thou canst well tell: O my fate!
I think she loves me, but I fear another
Is deeper in her heart: How thinkst thou Gobrias?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
I do beseech your Grace believe it not,
For let me perish if it be not false. Good Sir, read her Letter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
This Love, or what a devil it is I know not, begets
more mischief than a Wake. I had rather be well beaten,
starved, or lousy, than live within the Air of it. He that
had seen this brave fellow Charge through a grove of Pikes
but the other day, and look upon him now, will never believe
his eyes again: if he continue thus but two days more, a
Taylor may beat him with one hand tied behind him.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Alas, she would be at liberty.
And there be a thousand reasons Gobrias,
Thousands that will deny it:
Which if she knew, she would contentedly
Be where she is: and bless her virtues for it,
And me, though she were closer, she would, Gobrias,
Good man indeed she would.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Then good Sir, for her satisfaction,
Send for her and with reason make her know
Why she must live thus from you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I will; go bring her to me.

div2.stage: Enter Bessus, and two Sword-men, and a Boy.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
You are very welcome both; some stools boy,
And reach a Table; Gentlemen of the Sword,
Pray sit without more complement; be gone child.
I have been curious in the searching of you,
Because I understand you wise and valiant persons.
We understand ourselves Sir.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Nay Gentlemen, and dear friends of the Sword,
No complement I pray, but to the cause
I hang upon, which in few, is my honour.

You cannot hang too much Sir, for your honour,
But to your cause.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Be wise, and speak truth, my first doubt is,
My beating by my Prince.

Stay there a little Sir, do you doubt a beating?
Or have you had a beating by your Prince?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the Sword, my Prince has beaten me.
Brother, what think you of this case?
If he has beaten him, the case is clear.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Even with his Royal hand.
Was it a blow of love, or indignation?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
It was twenty blows of indignation, Gentlemen,
Besides two blows of the face.

Those blows on the face have made a new cause of it,
The rest were but an horrible rudeness.

Two blows on the face, and given by a worse man, I
must confess, as the Sword-men say, had turned the business:
Mark me brother, by a worse man; but being by his Prince,
had they been ten, and those ten drawn teeth, besides the
hazard of his nose forever; all this had been but favours:
this is my flat opinion, which I will die in.

The King may do much Captain, believe it; for had
he cracked your Scull through, like a bottle, or broke a Rib
or two with tossing of you, yet you had lost no honour:
This is strange you may imagine, but this is truth now
Captain.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
I will be glad to embrace it Gentlemen;
But how far may he strike me?

There is another: a new cause rising from the time
and distance, in which I will deliver my opinion: he may
strike, beat, or cause to be beaten: for these are natural
to man: your Prince, I say, may beat you, so far forth as
his dominion reacheth, that is for the distance; the time,
ten miles a day, I take it.

Brother, you err, it is fifteen miles a day,
His stage is ten, his beatings are fifteen.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: It is the longest, but we subjects must -
Be subject to it; you are wise and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Bes.

sp.p:
No trouble at all to us Sir, if we may
Profit your understanding, we are bound
By virtue of our calling to utter our opinions,
Shortly, and discreetly.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: My sorest business is, I have been kicked.
How far Sir?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Not to flatter myselfin it, all over, my sword
forced but not lost; for discreetly I rendered it to save that
imputation.
It showed discretion, the best part of valour.

Brother, this is a pretty cause, pray ponder on it;
Our friend here has been kicked.
Ho has so, brother.

Sorely he says: Now, had he set down here
Upon the mere kick, it had been Cowardly.
I think it had been Cowardly indeed.

But our friend has redeemed it in delivering
His sword without compulsion; and that man
That took it of him, I pronounce a weak one,
And his kicks nullities.
He should have kicked him after the delivering
Which is the confirmation of a Coward.

Brother, I take it, you mistake the question;
For, say that I were kicked.
But put the case I were kicked?

Let them put it that are things weary of their lives,
and know not honour; put the case you were kicked?
I do not say I was kicked.

Nor no silly creature that wears his head without a
Case, his soul in a Skin-coat: You kicked dear brother?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Nay Gentlemen, let us do what we shall do,
Truly and honesty; good Sirs to the question.
Why then I say, suppose your Boy kicked, Captain?
The Boy may be supposed is liable.

A foolish forward zeal Sir, in my friend;
But to the Boy, suppose the Boy were kicked.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I do suppose it.
Has your Boy a sword?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Surely no; I pray suppose a sword too.
I do suppose it; you grant your Boy was kicked then.

By no means Captain, let it be supposed still; the
word grant, makes not for us.
I say this must be granted.
This must be granted brother?
Aye, this must be granted.
Still this must?
I say this must be granted.
Aye, give me the must again, brother, you palter.
I will not hear you, wasp.

Brother, I say you palter, the must three times together;
I wear as sharp Steel as another man, and my Fox
bites as deep, musted, my dear brother.
But to the cause again.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Nay look you Gentlemen.
In a word, I have done.

A tall man but intemperate, it is great pity;
Once more suppose the Boy kicked.
Forward.
And being thoroughly kicked, laughs at the kicker.
So much for us; proceed.

And in this beaten scorn, as I may call it,
Delivers up his weapon; where lies the error?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: It lies in the beating Sir, I found it four days since.

The error, and a sore one as I take it,
Lies in the thing kicking.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I understand that well, it is so indeed Sir.
That is according to the man that did it.
There springs a new branch, whose was the foot?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: A Lords.

The cause is mighty, but had it been two Lords,
And both had kicked you, if you laugh, it is clear.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
I did laugh,
But how will that help me, Gentlemen?
Yes, it shall help you if you laughed aloud.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: As loud as a kicked man could laugh, I laughed Sir.

My reason now, the valiant man is known
By suffering and contemning; you have
Enough of both, and you are valiant.

If he be sure he has been kicked enough:
For that brave sufferance you speak of brother,
Consists not in a beating and away,
But in a cudgelled body, from eighteen
To eight and thirty; in a head rebuked
With pots of all size, degrees, stools, and bed-staves,
This shows a valiant man.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Then I am valiant; as valiant as the proudest,
For these are all familiar things to me;
Familiar as my sleep, or want of money,
All my whole body is but one bruise with beating,
I think I have been cudgelled with all nations,
And almost all Religions.

Embrace him brother, this man is valiant,
I know it by myself, he is valiant.

Captain, thou art a valiant Gentleman,
To bide upon, a very valiant man.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
My equal friends of the Sword, I must request your
hands to this.
It is fit it should be.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Boy, get me some wine, and pen and Ink within:
Am I clear, Gentlemen?

Sir, the world has taken notice what we have done,
Make much of your body, for I will pawn my steel,
Men will be coyer of their legs hereafter.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
I must request you go along and testify to the Lord
Bacurius, whose foot has struck me, how you find my cause.

We will, and tell that Lord he must be ruled,
Or there are those abroad, will rule his Lordship.

div2.stage: Enter Arbaces at one door, and Gob. and Panthea at another.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Sir, here is the Princess.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Leave us then alone,
For the main cause of her imprisonment
Must not be heard by any but herself.
You are welcome Sister, and would to heaven
I could so bid you by another name:
If you above love not such sins as these,
Circle my heart with thoughts as cold as snow
To quench these rising flames that harbour here.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Sir, does it please you I should speak?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Please me?
Aye, more than all the art of music can,
Thy speech doth please me, for it ever sounds,
As thou broughtest joyful unexpected news;
And yet it is not fit thou shouldest be heard.
I pray thee think so.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Be it so, I will.
Am I the first that ever had a wrong
So far from being fit to have redress,
That it was unfit to hear it? I will back
To prison, rather than disquiet you,
And wait till it be fit.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
No, do not go;
For I will hear thee with a serious thought:
I have collected all that is man about me
Together strongly, and I am resolved
To hear thee largely, but I do beseech thee,
Do not come nearer to me, for there is
Something in that, that will undo us both.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Alas Sir, am I venom?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Yes, to me;
Though of thyself I think thee to be
In equal degree of heat or cold,
As nature can make: yet as unsound men
Convert the sweetest and the nourishingest meats
Into diseases; so shall I distempered,
Do thee, I pray thee draw no nearer to me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Sir, this is that I would: I am of late
Shut from the world, and why it should be thus,
Is all I wish to know.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why credit me Panthea,
Credit me that am thy brother,
Thy loving brother, that there is a cause
Sufficient, yet unfit for thee to know,
That might undo thee everlastingly,
Only to hear, wilt thou but credit this?
By Heaven it is true, believe it if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Pan.
Arb.
sp.p:
Fie, you come in a step, what do you mean?
Dear sister, do not so: Alas Panthea,
Where I am would you be? Why that is the cause
You are imprisoned, that you may not be
Where I am.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Then I must endure it Sir, Heaven keep you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Nay, you shall hear the case in short Panthea,
And when thou hearest it, thou wilt blush for me,
And hang thy head down like a Violet
Full of the mornings dew: There is a way
To gain thy freedom, but it is such a one
As puts thee in worse bondage, and I know,
Thou wouldst encounter fire, and make a proof
Whether the gods have care of innocence,
Rather than follow it: Know that I have lost,
The only difference betwixt man and beast,
My reason.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Nay it is gone;
And I am left as far without a bound,
As the wild Ocean, that obeys the winds;
Each sudden passion throws me where it lists,
And overwhelms all that oppose my will:
I have beheld thee with a lustful eye;
My heart is set on wickedness to act
Such sins with thee, as I have been afraid
To think of, if thou darest consent to this,
Which I beseech thee do not, thou mayest gain
Thy liberty, and yield me a content;
If not, thy dwelling must be dark and close,
Where I may never see thee; For heaven knows
That laid this punishment upon my pride,
Thy sight at some time will enforce my madness
To make a start even to thy ravishing;
Now spit upon me, and call all reproaches
Thou canst devise together, and at once
Hurl them against me: for I am a sickness
As killing as the plague, ready to seize thee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Far be it from me to revile the King:
But it is true, that I shall rather choose
To search out death, that else would search out me,
And in a grave sleep with my innocence,
Than welcome such a sin: It is my fate,
To these cross accidents I was ordained,
And must have patience; and but that my eyes
Have more of woman in them than my heart,
I would not weep: Peace enter you again.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Farewell, and good Panthea pray for me,
Thy prayers are pure, that I may find a death
However soon before my passions grow
That they forget what I desire is sin;
For thither they are tending: if that happen,
Then I shall force thee though thou wert a Virgin
By vow to Heaven, and shall pull a heap
Of strange yet uninvented sin upon me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Sir, I will pray for you, yet you shall know
It is a sullen fate that governs us,
For I could wish as heartily as you
I were no sister to you, I should then
Embrace your lawful love, sooner than health.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Couldst thou affect me then?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
So perfectly,
That as it is, I never shall sway my heart,
To like another.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Then I curse my birth,
Must this be added to my miseries
That thou art willing too? is there no stop
To our full happiness, but these mere sounds
Brother and Sister?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
There is nothing else,
But these alas will separate us more
Than twenty worlds betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I have lived
To conquer men and now am overthrown
Only by words Brother and Sister: where
Have those words dwelling? I will find them out,
And utterly destroy them; but they are
Not to be grasped: let them be men or beasts,
And I will cut them from the Earth, or Towns,
And I will raze them, and them blow them up:
Let them be Seas, and I will drink them off,
And yet have unquenched fire left in my breast:
Let them be anything but merely voice.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
But it is not in the power of any force,
Or policy to conquer them.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Panthea, What shall we do?
Shall we stand firmly here, and gaze our eyes out?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Would I could do so,
But I shall weep out mine.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Accursed man,
Thou boughtest thy reason at too dear a rate,
For thou hast all thy actions bounded in
With curious rules, when every beast is free:
What is there that acknowledges a kindred
But wretched man? Who ever saw the Bull
Fearfully leave the Heifer that he liked
Because they had one Dam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Sir, I disturb you and myself too;
It were better I were gone.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I will not be so foolish as I was,
Stay, we will love just as becomes our births,
No otherwise: Brothers and Sisters may
Walk hand in hand together; so will we,
Come nearer: is there any hurt in this?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Faith there is none at all:
And tell me truly now, is there not one
You love above me?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No by Heaven.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why yet you sent unto Tigranes, Sister.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: True, but for another: for the truth -

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
No more,
I will credit thee, thou canst not lie,
Thou art all truth.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
But is there nothing else,
That we may do, but only walk? methinks
Brothers and Sisters lawfully may kiss.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
And so they may Panthea, so will we,
And kiss again too; we were too scrupulous,
And foolish, but we will be so no more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
If you have any mercy, let me go
To prison, to my death, to anything:
I feel a sin growing upon my blood,
Worse than all these, hotter than yours.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: That is impossible, what should we do?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Fly Sir, for Heavens sake.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
So we must away,
Sin grows upon us more by this delay.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sir, the King has seen your Commission, and
believes it, and freely by this warrant gives
you power to visit Prince Tigranes, your Noble Master.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: I thank his Grace and kiss his hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But is the main of all your business ended in this?

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
I have another, but a worse, I am ashamed, it is
a business.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
You serve a worthy person, and a stranger I am sure
you are; you may employ me if you please without your
purse, such Offices should ever be their own rewards.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: I am bound to your Nobleness.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I may have need of you, and then this courtesy,
If it be any, is not ill bestowed;
But may I civilly desire the rest?
I shall not be a hurter if no helper.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Sir you shall know I have lost a foolish Daughter,
And with her all my patience, pilfered away
By a mean Captain of your Kings.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Stay there Sir:
If he have reached the Noble worth of Captain,
He may well claim a worthy Gentlewoman,
Though she were yours, and Noble.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
I grant all that too: but this wretched fellow
Reaches no further than the empty name
That serves to feed him; were he valiant,
Or had but in him any noble nature
That might hereafter promise him a good man,
My cares were so much lighter, and my grave
A span yet from me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I confess such fellows
Be in all Royal Camps, and have and must be,
To make the sin of Coward more detested
In the mean soldier that with such a foil
Sets off much valour. By description
I should now guess him to you, it was Bessus,
I dare almost with confidence pronounce it.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: It is such a scurvy name as Bessus, and now I think it is he.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Captain do you call him?
Believe me Sir, you have a misery
Too mighty for your age: A pox upon him,
For that must be the end of all his service:
Your Daughter was not mad Sir?

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
No, would she had been,
The fault had had more credit: I would do something.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I would fain counsel you, but to what I know not,
he is so below a beating, that the Women find him not
worthy of their Distaffs, and to hang him were to cast away
a Rope; he is such an Airy, thin unbodied Coward,
that no revenge can catch him: I will tell you Sir, and tell
you truth; this Rascal fears neither God nor man, he has
been so beaten: sufferance has made him Wainscot: he
has had since he was first a slave, at least three hundred
Daggers set in his head, as little boys do new Knives in hot
meat, there is not a Rib in his body onmy Conscience that
has not been thrice broken with dry beating: and now his
sides look like two Wicker Targets, every way bended;
Children will shortly take him for a Wall, and set their
Stone-bows in his forehead, he is of so base a sense, I cannot
in a week imagine what shall be done to him.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Sure I have committed some great sin
That this fellow should be made my Rod,
I would see him, but I shall have no patience.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
It is no great matter if you have not: if a Laming
of him, or such a toy may do you pleasure Sir, he has
it for you, and I will help you to him: it is no news to him
to have a Leg broken, or Shoulder out, with being turned
on the stones like a Tansy: draw not your Sword if you love
it; for on my Conscience his head will break it: we use
him in the Wars - like a Ram to shake a wall withal. Here
comes the very person of him, do as you shall and your
temper, I must leave you: but if you do not break him like
a Biscuit, you are much to blame Sir.

div2.stage: Enter Bessus and the Sword men.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: Is your name Bessus?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Men call me Captain Bessus.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Then Captain Bessus, you are a rank rascal, without
more exordiums, a dirty frozen slave; and with the
favour of your friends here I will beat you.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p:
Pray use your pleasure Sir,
You seem to be a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Thus Captain Bessus, thus; thus twing your nose,
thus kick, thus tread you.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I do beseech you yield your cause Sir quickly.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: Indeed I should have told that first.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I take it so.

sp.speaker: 1 Sword.
sp.p: Captain, he should indeed, he is mistaken.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Sir, you shall have it quickly, and more beating,
you have stolen away a Lady, Captain coward, and such
an one.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Hold, I beseech you, hold Sir, I never yet stole any
living thing that had a tooth about it.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: I know you dare lie.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
With none but Summer Whores upon my life Sir,
my means and manners never could attempt above a hedge
or hay cock.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Sirrah, that quits not me, where is this Lady? do
that you do not use to do; tell truth, or by my hand, I will
beat your Captains brains out, wash them, and put them in
again, that will I.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
There was a Lady Sir, I must confess, once in my
charge: the Prince Tigranes gave her to my guard for her
safety, how I used her, she may herselfreport, she is with
the Prince now: I did but wait upon her like a groom,
which she will testify I am sure: if not, my brains are at
your service when you please Sir, and glad I have them
for you.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
This is most likely, Sir, I ask you pardon, and am
sorry I was so intemperate.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Well I can ask no more, you will think it strange
not to have me beat you at first sight.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Indeed I would, but I know your goodness can forget
twenty beatings, you must forgive me.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Yes there is my hand, go where you will, I shall
think you a valiant fellow for all this.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
My daughter is a Whore, I feel it now too sensible;
yet I will see her, discharge myselffrom being father to
her, and then back to my Country, and there die, farewell
Captain.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Farewell Sir, farewell, commend me to the gentlewoman
I pray.

sp.speaker: 1 Sword.
sp.p: How now Captain? bear up man.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Gentlemen of the sword, your hands once more; I
have been kicked again, but the foolish fellow is penitent, has
asked me Mercy, and my honour is safe.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p:
We knew that, or the foolish fellow had better
have kicked his grandsire.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Confirm, confirm I pray.

sp.speaker: 1 Sword.
sp.p:
There be our hands again, now let him come
and say he was not sorry, and he sleeps for it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Alas good ignorant old man, let him go, let him
go, these courses will undo him.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
My Lord, your authority is good, and I am glad it is
so, for my consent would never hinder you from seeing your
own King, I am a Minister, but not a governor of this State,
yonder is your King, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: There he is indeed, and with him my disloyal child.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
I do perceive my fault so much, that yet methinks
thou shouldest not have forgiven me.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: Health to your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
What? good Lygones welcome, what business
brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Several businesses. My public businesses will appear
by this, I have a message to deliver, which if it please
you so to authorize, is an embassage from the Armenian
State, unto Arbaces for your liberty: the offer is there set
down, please you to read it.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: There is no alteration happened since I came thence?

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: None Sir, all is as it was.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: And all our friends are well?

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: All very well.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Though I have done nothing but what was good, I
dare not see my Father, it was fault enough not to acquaint
him with that good.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: Madam I should have seen you.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: O good Sir forgive me.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: Forgive you, why? I am no kin to you, am I?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
Should it be measured by my mean deserts, indeed
you are not.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Thou couldst prate unhappily ere thou couldst go,
would thou couldst do as well, and how does your custom
hold out here?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: Are you in private still, or how?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Do you take money? are you come to sell sin yet
perhaps I can help you to liberal Clients: or has not the
King cast you off yet? O thou vile creature, whose best
commendation is, that thou art a young whore, I would
thy Mother had lived to see this, or rather that I had died
ere I had seen it; why didst not make me acquainted when
thou wert first resolved to be a whore, I would have seen thy
hot lust satisfied more privately: I would have kept a dancer
and a whole consort of musicians in my own house only to
fiddle thee.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Sir, I was never whore.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
If thou couldst not say so much for thyself, thou
shouldest be carted.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Lygones, I have read it, and I like it, you shall
deliver it.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Well Sir, I will: but I have private business with
you.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Speak, what is it?

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
How has my age deserved so ill of you, that you can
pick no strumpets in the land, but out of my breed?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Strumpets, good Lygones?

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Yes, and I wish to have you know, I scorn to get a
whore for any prince alive, and yet scorn will not help methinks:
my Daughter might have been spared, there were
enough besides.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
May I not prosper but she is innocent as morning
light for me, and I dare swear for all the world.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Why is she with you then? can she wait on you
better than your man, has she a gift in plucking off your
stockings, can she make Caudles well or cut your corns?
Why do you keep her with you? For a Queen I know you
do contemn her, so should I, and every subject else think
much at it.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Let them think much, but it is more firm than earth:
thou seest thy Queen there.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Then have I made a fair hand, I called her Whore.
If I shall speak now as her Father, I cannot choose but greatly
rejoice that she shall be a Queen: but if I shall speak to
you as a States-man, she were more fit to be your whore.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Get you about your business to Arbaces, now you
talk idly.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Yes Sir, I will go, and shall she be a Queen? she
had more wit than her old Father, when she ran away: shall
she be Queen? now by my troth it is fine, I will dance out of
all measure at her wedding: shall I not Sir?

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Yes marry shalt thou.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
I will make these withered kexes bear my body two
hours together above ground.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Nay go, my business requires haste.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Good-Heaven preserve you, you are an excellent
King.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Farewell good Father.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Farewell sweet virtuous Daughter, I never was so
joyful in all my life, that I remember: shall she be a Queen?
Now I perceive a man may weep for joy, I had thought they
had lied that said so.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: Come my dear love.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: But you may see another may alter that again.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
Urge it no more, I have made up a new strong constancy,
not to be shook with eyes: I know I have the passions
of a man, but if I meet with any subject that should hold my
eyes more firmly than is fit, I will think of thee, and run
away from it: let that suffice.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Three Gentlemen without to speak with me?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Let them come in.

div2.stage: Enter Bessus with the two Sword men.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They are entered Sir already.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Now fellows your business? are these the Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
My Lord, I have made bold to bring these Gentlemen,
my friends of the Sword along with me.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: I am afraid you will fight then.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
My good Lord, I will not, your Lordship is much
mistaken, fear not Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Sir, I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
I ask no more in honour, Gentlemen you hear my
Lord is sorry.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Not that I have beaten you, but beaten one that
will be beaten: one whose dull body will require a laming,
as Surfeits do the diet, spring and fall; now to your Sword-men;
what come they for, good Captain Stock-fish?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: It seems your Lordship has forgot my name.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
No, nor your nature neither, though they are
things fitter I must confess for anything, than my remembrance,
or any honest man's: what shall these Billets do;
be piled up in my wood-yard?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Your Lordship holds your mirth still, Heaven continue
it: but for these Gentlemen, they come -

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
To swear you are a Coward, spare your book, I
do believe it.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Your Lordship still draws wide, they come to vouch
under their valiant hands I am no Coward.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
That would be a show indeed worth seeing: sirrah
be wise, and take Money for this motion, travel with it,
and where the name of Bessus has been known or a good
Coward stirring, it will yield more than a tilting. This will
prove more beneficial to you, if you be thrifty, than your
Captainship, and more natural: men of most valiant hands
is this true?

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p: It is so, most renowned.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: It is somewhat strange.

sp.speaker: 1 Sword.
sp.p:
Lord, it is strange, yet true; we have examined
from your Lordships foot there, to this man's head, the
nature of the beatings; and we do find his honour is come
off clean and sufficient: this as our swords shall help us.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
You are much bound to your bill-bow-men, I am
glad you are straight again Captain; it were good you
would think on some way to gratify them, they have undergone
a labour for you, Bessus, would have puzzled Hercules
with all his valour.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p:
Your Lordship must understand we are no men
of the Law, that take pay for our opinions: it is sufficient we have cleared our friend.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Yet there is something due, which I as touched in
Conscience will discharge Captain; I will pay this Rent for you.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Spare yourselfmy good Lord; my brave friends
aim at nothing but the virtue.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: That is but a cold discharge Sir for the pains.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p: O Lord, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Be not so modest, I will give you something.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: They shall dine with your Lordship, that is sufficient.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Something in hand the while, you Rogues, you
Apple-squires: do you come hither with your bottled valour,
your windy froth, to limit out my beatings?

sp.speaker: 1 Sword.
sp.p: I do beseech your Lordship.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p: O good Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
'sfoot what a bevy of beaten slaves are here? get
me a Cudgel sirrah, and a tough one.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p: More of your foot, I do beseech your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: You shall, you shall dog, and your fellow-beagle.

sp.speaker: 1 Sword.
sp.p: On this side good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Off with your swords, for if you hurt my foot, I will
have you flayed you Rascals.

sp.speaker: 1 Sword.
sp.p: Mine is off my Lord.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p:
I beseech your Lordship stay a little, my strap is
tied to my Cod piece-point: now when you please.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Captain these are your valiant friends, you long
for a little too?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: I am very well, I humbly thank your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
What is that in your pocket, hurts my Toe you
Mongrel? Thy Buttocks cannot be so hard, out with it
quickly.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p:
Here it is Sir, a small piece of Artillery, that a
Gentleman a dear friend of your Lordships sent me with,
to get it mended Sir, for if you mark, the nose is somewhat
loose.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
A friend of mine you Rascal? I was never wearier
of doing anything, than kicking these two Foot-balls.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here is a good Cudgel Sir.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
It comes too late I am weary, pray thee do thou
beat them.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p:
My Lord, this is foul play i'faith, to put a
fresh man upon us, men are but men Sir.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
That jest shall save your bones; Captain, Rally up
your rotten Regiment and be gone: I had rather thrash
than be bound to kick these Rascals, till they cried ho;
Bessus you may put your hand to them now, and then you
are quit. Farewell, as you like this, pray visit me again,
it will keep me in good health.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p: He has a devilish hard foot, I never felt the like.

sp.speaker: 1 Sword.
sp.p: Nor I, and yet I am sure I have felt a hundred.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p:
If he kick thus in the Dog-days, he will be dry
foundered: what cure now Captain besides Oil of Bays?

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p: Why well enough I warrant you, you can go.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p:
Yes, heaven be thanked; but I feel a shrowd
ache, sure he has sprang my huckle-bone.

sp.speaker: 1 Sword.
sp.p: I have lost a haunch.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
A little butter, friend a little butter, butter and
parsley and a sovereign matter: probatum est.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p:
Captain we must request your hand now to our
honours.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Yes marry shall ye, and then let all the world come,
we are valiant to ourselves, and there is an end.

sp.speaker: 1 Sword.
sp.p: Nay then we must be valiant; O my ribs.

sp.speaker: 2 Sword.
sp.p:
O my small guts, a plague upon these sharp-toed
shoes, they are murtherers.

div2.stage: Enter Arbaces with his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
It is resolved, I bare it whilst I could, I can no
more, I must begin with murther of my friends, and so go
on to that incestuous ravishing, and end my life and sins
with a forbidden blow, upon myself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
What Tragedy is near? That hand was never
wont to draw a sword, but it cried dead to something.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Mardonius, have you bid Gobrias come?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Well, is he coming?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Why Sir, are you thus? why do your hands proclaim
a lawless War against yourself?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Thou answerest me one question with an other, is
Gobrias coming?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir he is.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It is well, I can forbear your questions then, be gone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, I have marked.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Mark less, it troubles you and me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You are more variable than you were.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Today no Hermit could be humbler than you were
to us all.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And what of this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
And now you take new rage into your eyes, as you
would look us all out of the Land.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I do confess it, will that satisfy? I prithee get thee
gone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, I will speak.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Will ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
It is my duty. I fear you will kill yourself: I am
a subject, and you shall do me wrong in it: it is my cause, and
I may speak.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Thou art not trained in sin, it seems Mardonius: kill
myself! by Heaven I will not do it yet; and when I will,
I will tell thee then; I shall be such a creature, that thou wilt
give me leave without a word. There is a method in man's
wickedness, it grows up by degrees: I am not come so high
as killing of myself, there are a hundred thousand sins
betwixt me and it, which I must do, and I shall come to it at
last; but take my oath not now, be satisfied, and get thee
hence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am sorry it is so ill.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Be sorry then, true sorrow is alone, grieve by
thyself.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I pray you let me see your Sword put up before I
go: I will leave you then.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why so? what folly is this in thee, is it not as apt
to mischief as it was before? can I not reach it thinkst
thou? these are toys for Children to be pleased with, and
not men, now I am safe you think: I would the book of fate
were here, my Sword is not so sure but I would get it out
and mangle that, that all the destinies should quite forget
their fixed decrees, and hast to make us new, for other fortunes,
mine could not be worse, wilt thou now leave me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Heaven put into your bosom temperate thoughts,
I will leave you though I fear.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Go, thou art honest, why should the hasty error of
my youth be so unpardonable to draw a sin helpless upon
me?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: There is the King, now it is ripe.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Draw near thou guilty man, that art the author of
the loathedest crime five ages have brought forth, and hear
me speak; curses more incurable, and all the evils man's
body or his Spirit can receive be with thee.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Why Sir do you curse me thus?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why do I curse thee? if there be a man subtle in
curses, that exceeds the rest, his worst wish on thee, thou
hast broke my heart.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
How Sir, have I preserved you from a child, from
all the arrows, malice, or ambition could shoot at you, and
have I this for my pay?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
It is true, thou didst preserve me, and in that wert
crueler than hardened murtherers of infants and their
Mothers? thou didst save me only till thou hadst studied
out a way how to destroy me cunningly thyself: this was a
curious way of torturing.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Thou knowest the evils thou hast done to me; dost
thou remember all those witching letters thou sentest unto
me to Armenia, filled with the praise of my beloved Sister,
where thou extollest her beauty, what had I to do with that?
what could her beauty be to me? and thou didst write how
well she loved me, dost thou remember this? so that I
doted something before I saw her.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: This is true.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Is it? and when I was returned thou knowest thou
didst pursue it, till thou woundest me into such a strange and
unbelieved affection, as good men cannot think on.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: This I grant, I think I was the cause.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Wert thou? Nay more, I think thou meantest it.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Sir, I hate to lie, as I love Heaven and honesty, I
did, it was my meaning.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Be thine own sad judge, a further condemnation will
not need, prepare thyself to die.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Why Sir to die?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why shouldest thou live? was ever yet offender so
impudent, that had a thought of Mercy after confession of
a crime like this? get out I cannot where thou hurlest me
in, but I can take revenge, that is all the sweetness left for me.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Now is the time, hear me but speak.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
No, yet I will be far more merciful than thou
wert to me; thou didst steal into me and never gavest me
warning: so much time as I give thee now, had prevented
thee forever. Notwithstanding all thy sins, if thou hast
hope, that there is yet a prayer to save thee, turn and speak
it to thyself.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Sir, you shall know your sins before you do them, if
you kill me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I will not stay then.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Know you kill your Father.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You kill your Father.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
My Father? though I know it for a lie, made out
of fear to save thy stained life; the very reverence of the
word comes cross me, and ties mine arm down.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
I will tell you that shall heighten you again, I am
thy Father, I charge thee hear me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
If it should be so, as it is most false, and that I
should be found a Bastard issue, the despised fruit of lawless
lust, I should no more admire all my wild passions: but another
truth shall be wrung from thee: if I could come by the
Spirit of pain, it should be poured on thee, till thou allowest
thyself more full of lies than he that teaches thee.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p:
Turn thee about, I come to speak to thee thou
wicked man, hear me thou tyrant.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I will turn to thee, hear me thou Strumpet; I have
blotted out the name of Mother, as thou hast thy shame.

sp.speaker: Ara.
Arb.
sp.p:
Cease thy strange impudence, and answer quickly
if thou contemnest me, this will ask an answer, and have
it.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Help me Gentle Gobrias.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Guilt dare not help guilt though they grow together
in doing ill, yet at the punishment they sever, and each
flies the noise of other, think not of help, answer.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I will, to what?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
To such a thing, as if it be a truth think what a
creature thou hast made thyself, that didst not shame to do,
what I must blush only to ask thee: tell me who I am,
whose son I am without all circumstance, be thou as hasty as
my Sword will be if thou refusest.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Why, you are his son.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
His Son? swear, swear, thou worse than woman
damned.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: By all that is good you are.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Then art thou all that ever was known bad, now is
the cause of all my strange misfortunes come to light: what
reverence expectest thou from a child, to bring forth which
thou hast offended heaven, thy husband, and the Land?
adulterous witch, I know now why thou wouldst have poisoned
me, I was thy lust which thou wouldst have forgot:
then wicked Mother of my sins, and me, show me the way
to the inheritance I have by thee: which is a spacious world
of impious acts, that I may soon possess it: plagues rot thee,
as thou livest, and such diseases, as use to pay lust, recompense
thy deed.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: You do not know why you curse thus.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Too well; you are a pair of Vipers; and behold
the Serpent you have got; there is no beast but if he knew
it, has a pedigree as brave as mine, for they have more
descents, and I am every way as beastly got, as far without
the compass of Law as they.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p:
You spend your rage and words in vain, and rail
upon a guess; hear us a little.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
No, I will never hear, but talk away my breath,
and die.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Why, but you are no Bastard.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Nor child of mine.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Still you go on in wonders to me.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Pray you be more patient, I may bring comfort to you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I will kneel, and hear with the obedience of a
child; good Father speak, I do acknowledge you, so you
bring comfort.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
First know, our last King, your supposed Father
was old and feeble when he married her, and almost all
the Land thought she was past hope of issue from him.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Therefore she took leave to play the whore, because
the King was old: is this the comfort?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p:
What will you find out to give me satisfaction,
when you find how you have injured me? let fire consume
one, if ever I were a whore.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
For-bear these starts, or I will leave you wedded to
despair, as you are now: if you can find a temper, my
breath shall be a pleasant western wind that cools and
blasts not.

sp.speaker: Arb.
Gob.
sp.p:
Our King I say, was old, and this our Queen desired
to bring an heir, but yet her husband she thought was past
it, and to be dishonest I think she would not: if she would
have been, the truth is, she was watched so narrowly, and had
so slender opportunities, she hardly could have been: but yet
her cunning found out this way; she feigned herselfwith
child, and posts were sent in haste throughout the Land, and
humble thanks was given in every Church, and prayers were
made for her safe going and delivery: she feigned now to
grow bigger, and perceived this hope of issue made her
feared, and brought a far more large respect from every
man, and saw her power increase, and was resolved, since she
believed, she could not have it indeed, at least she would be
thought to have a child.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Do I not hear it well? nay I will make no noise at
fall; but pray you to the point, quickly as you can.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p:
Now when the time was full, she should be brought
to bed, I had a Son born, which was you, this the Queen
hearing of moved me to let her have you; and such reasons
she showed me, as she knew would tie my secrecy, she swore
you should be King, and to be short, I did deliver you unto
her, and pretended you were dead, and in mine own house
kept a funeral, and had an empty coffin put in Earth, that
night this Queen feigned hastily to labour and by a pair of
women of her own, which she had charmed, she made the
world believe she was delivered of you. You grew up as
the Kings Son, till you were six years old; then did the King
dye, and did leave to me Protection of the Realm; and
contrary to his own expectation, left this Queen truly with
child indeed, of the fair Princess Panthea: then she could
have torn her hair and did alone to me, yet durst not speak
in public, for she knew she should be found a traitor: and
her tale would have been thought madness, or anything rather
than truth. This was the only cause why she did seek
to poison you, and I to keep you safe; and this the reason,
why I fought to kindle some sparks of love in you to fair
Panthea, that she might get part of her right again.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
And have you made an end now? is this all? if
not, I will be still till I be aged, till all my hairs be Silver.

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And is it true say you too Madam?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Yes heaven knows it is most true.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Panthea then is not my Sister?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: But can you prove this?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: If you will give consent, else who dares go about it?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Give consent? why I will have them all that know it
racked, to get this from them, all that wait without come in,
whatever you be; come in and be partakers of my joy, O
you are welcome.

div2.stage: Enter Bessus, Gentlemen, Mardonius, and other attendants.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
The best news, nay draw no nearer, they all shall
hear it, I am found no King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is that so good news?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Yes the happiest news that ever was heard.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Indeed it were well for you if you might be a
little less obeyed.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: One call the Queen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why she is there.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
The Queen Mardonius, Panthea is the Queen and
I am plain Arbaces; go someone, she is in Gobrias house,
since I saw you there are a thousand things delivered to me,
you little dream of.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So it should seem my Lord, what fury is this?

sp.speaker: Gob.
sp.p: Believe me it is no fury, all that he says is truth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It is very strange.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why do you keep your hats off Gentlemen? is
it to me? I swear it must not be; nay, trust me, in good
faith it must not be; I cannot now command you, but I
pray you for the respect you bare me, when you took me for
your King, each man clap on his hat at my desire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
We will, you are not found so mean a man, but
that you may be covered as well as we, may you not?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
O not here, you may, but not I, for here is my
Father in presence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Why there: O the whole story would be a wilderness
to lose thyself forever: O pardon me dear Father for
all the idle and unreverent words that I have spoke in idle
moods to you: I am Arbaces, we all fellow-subjects,
nor is the Queen Panthea now my Sister.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Why if you remember fellow-subject Arbaces; I
told you once she was not your Sister: I, and she looked nothing
like you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I think you did, good Captain Bessus.

sp.speaker: Bes.
sp.p:
Here will arise another question now amongst the
Sword-men, whether I be to call him to account for beating
me, now he is proved no King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir here is Lygones, the agent for the Armenian State.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Where is he? I know your business good
Lygones.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: We must have our King again, and will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
I knew that was your business: you shall have your
King again, and have him so again as never King was had,
go one of you and bid Bacurius bring Tigranes hither;
and bring the Lady with him, that Panthea, the Queen
Panthea sent me word this morning, was brave Tigranes
mistress.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: It is Spaconia.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, Spaconia.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p: She is my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
She is so: I could now tell anything I never heard:
your King shall go so home, as never man went.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Shall he go on his head?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
He shall have chariots easier than air that I will
have invented; and never think one shall pay any ransom,
and thyself that art the messenger, shalt ride before him
on a horse cut out of an entire Diamond, that shall be made
to go with golden wheels, I know not how yet.

sp.speaker: Lyg.
sp.p:
Why I shall be made forever? they belied this King
with us, and said he was unkind.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
And then thy Daughter, she shall have some strange
thing, we will have the Kingdom sold utterly, and put into a
toy which she shall wear about her carelessly some where or
other. See the virtuous Queen; behold the humblest subject
that you have kneel here before you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Why kneel you to me that am your Vassal?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Grant me one request.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Alas what can I grant you? what I can, I will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
That you will please to marry me if I can prove it
lawful.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Is that all? more willingly than I would draw this
air.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I will kiss this hand in earnest.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p:
Sir, Tigranes is coming though he made it
strange at first, to see the Princess any more.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
The Queen thou meanest, O my Tigranes. Pardon
me, tread on my neck, I freely offer it, and if thou beest so
given take revenge, for I have injured thee.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p:
No, I forgive, and rejoice more that you have
found repentance, than I my liberty.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Mayest thou be happy in thy fair choice, for thou
art temperate. You owe no ransom to the state, know that
I have a thousand joys to tell you of, which yet I dare not
utter till I pay my thanks to Heaven for them: Will you go
with me and help me? pray you do.

sp.speaker: Tigr.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p:
Take then your fair one with you; and you Queen
of goodness and of us, O give me leave to take your
arm in mine: come everyone that takes delight in
goodness, help to sing loud thanks for me, that I am proved
no King.
